title.narrative: Saving Lives Corporate Indicators
WSH-I4: Number of people having access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use

description.narrative: Access: maximum distance to water point 500m, queuing time less than 15min, filling time maximum 3 min/20 litres or as locally agreed. Water access should be during the whole period of implementation unless action is mostly related to building the local water delivery capacity. Sufficient: covering basic needs, i.e. 7.5-15 l/p/d or as locally agreed. Safe: 1) low risk of faecal contamination, 2) No faecal coliforms detectable in any 100-ml sample, 3) For piped water supplies, or for all water supplies at times of risk or presence of diarrhoea epidemic, water is treated with a disinfectant to achieve free chlorine residual at the tap of 0.5 mg per litre and turbidity is below 5 NTU, 4) If for a short period, water which is contaminated chemically or radiologically is used, no (significant probability of) negative health effect is (likely to be) detected. Domestic use: drinking, cooking and personal hygiene (incl. laundry)

title.narrative: CSH-I2: Number of people benefitting from conditional and unrestricted cash transfers

description.narrative: A conditional transfer requires beneficiaries to undertake a specific action/activity (e.g. attending school, building a shelter, attending nutrition screenings, undertaking work, trainings, etc.) in order to receive assistance; i.e. a condition must be fulfilled before the transfer is received. Unrestricted transfers can be used entirely as the recipient chooses i.e. there are no restrictions on how the transfer is spent (Definitions of CALP). Conditional cash transfers can include cash for work, cash for assets and cash for training.

title.narrative: CSH-I1: Number of people benefitting from unconditional and unrestricted cash transfers

description.narrative: Unconditional transfers are provided to beneficiaries without the recipient having to do anything in return in order to receive the assistance . Unrestricted transfers can be used entirely as the recipient chooses i.e. there are no restrictions on how the transfer is spent (Definitions of CALP). It can be delivered e.g. through local banks, shops, traders, local money transfer companies, remittance companies and post offices in either one or several instalments.

Flood Resilience in Myanmar Dry Zone.

description.narrative: Pakokku Township is located in Magway region, in the centre of Myanmar. The economy of the Township is defined by agriculture, especially in the rural areas. Pakokku has five different zones, reflecting on their environmental profile: 1) Pakokku town; 2) riverbank areas; 3) seasonal flash flood (wet-dry) areas; 4) inland dry areas; and 5) mountain dry areas. These zones are differently influenced by natural hazards. The main challenge in the township is the vulnerability related to water. The dry zone receives little rain (average of 650mm) on an annual basis. However, during July-October storms, it floods quickly in the area, partly because of decreasing forest cover and soil erosion. This places communities at higher risk of localised flash floods during times of heavy rain. The targeted community is located along the Ayeyarwaddy river bank. As a result of climate change and the uncertainty of climatic conditions, plus deforestation and changed land-use, hydrological risks are increasing, especially in flood prone areas. Additionally, the area has a very unbalanced sex ratio, because of the out-migration of men. Also the infant mortality is considerably higher than the national average.

The aim of the project is to build the resilience of (13) communities in Pakokku Township and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social, and environmental shocks and disasters.

The project targets 13 villages in Pakokku Township, with a total number of 1511 households, consisting of 7395 individuals (3,473 male and 3,922 female). The direct benefit of improved resilience will improve the resilience of the whole township, through increased attention on this topic and disaster risk reduction measures which are carried out. The indirect target group has 29 villages and a population of approximately 10,150.

Strengthening The Health System In Jimma Zone

description.narrative:
General Objective: “Improved availability and accessibility of good quality healthcare at primary and secondary level in the Jimma Zone (Oromia Region, Ethiopia), and a stronger health system at large, which supports the progressive realization of Universal Health Coverage (SDG 3.8) in this geographical area.”
The three (inter-related) targeted Outcomes are:
1. Improved Health Service Delivery in 13 woredas of the Jimma Zone, reflected in: A. Increased utilization of good quality services B. Increased equity in access
2. Improved governance of health service delivery through: A. Increased capacity of 13 Woreda Health Offices and 1 Zonal Health Department B. Institutionalisation of PBF in the Ethiopian health system
3. An enhanced health information system that supports: A. Data based decision making at Woreda, Zonal and Regional level B. Additional financing potential for health system through enhanced transparency

In Ethiopia, Cordaid started to showcase Performance Based Financing in the arid and pastoralist Borana zone of the Oromia region since May 1st, 2015. At first in 4 Borana districts and with 9 Health facilities but as of July 2018 scaling it up to 8 Borana districts with in total 25 Health facilities with a catchment population of 488,556. Both PBF Borana phases are supported by Cordaid funds.
Halfway 2018 Cordaid was invited by the Netherlands Embassy to formulate a four year proposal and budget for scaling up PBF in the rural coffee growing zone of Jimma. Early April 2019 the Embassy approved the four year project proposal using as starting date the 1st of April 2019. During the first six months the project will be set up and staff recruited and trained. The first quarter for which the health facilities will be contracted under PBF will be October to December 2019.

The project will focus on 13 Jimma zone districts (of the in total 21 Jimma districts). It will work mostly via health facilities. In total 65 Health Centers and 5 Hospitals will be contracted under the PBF project. In total these facilities have a catchment population of 1.828.148 people living in the 13 targeted districts of the Jimma zone.

title.narrative: Emergency Response Earthquake Sulawesi

description.narrative:
Humanitarian emergency life saving response after the earthquake/ tsunami in Sulawesi, Indonesia. Giro555 started a National Appeal on October 2nd to raise funds for the victims of the disaster and Cordaid is a member agency that is supporting a local partner network on humanitarian response.
To ensure early recovery (3-8 months after disaster) and resilient recovery (8-24 months after disaster) to prevent the disaster to recur

Indonesia was struck by a 7.5 magnitude followed by a tsunami on 29 September 2018, killing so far more than 800 people and affecting directly and indirectly more than 2 million people. Local infrastructure was heavily destroyed and the population now struggle to survive. There are high needs in shelter, WASH, food and non-food items, but access is a challenge due to destruction. The government has officially requested for international assistance.
People affected by the earthquake. Target: 2000 HH or 8000 people

participating-org.narrative: LPTP - Lembanga Pengembangan Teknologi Predesaan Indonesia

title.narrative: Water Supply
WSH-I4: Number of people having access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use

description.narrative: Access: maximum distance to water point 500m, queuing time less than 15min, filling time maximum 3 min/20 litres or as locally agreed. Water access should be during the whole period of implementation unless action is mostly related to building the local water delivery capacity. Sufficient: covering basic needs, i.e. 7.5-15 l/p/d or as locally agreed. Safe: 1) low risk of faecal contamination, 2) No faecal coliforms detectable in any 100-ml sample, 3) For piped water supplies, or for all water supplies at times of risk or presence of diarrhoea epidemic, water is treated with a disinfectant to achieve free chlorine residual at the tap of 0.5 mg per litre and turbidity is below 5 NTU, 4) If for a short period, water which is contaminated chemically or radiologically is used, no (significant probability of) negative health effect is (likely to be) detected. Domestic use: drinking, cooking and personal hygiene (incl. laundry)

title.narrative: Individual household shelter
SHL-I1: Number of people having access to basic, safe and dignified shelters solutions

description.narrative: Basic, safe and dignified: - affected individuals have an minimum covered floor area of 3.5m2 per person. - all shelter solutions and materials meet locally agreed technical and performance standards and are culturally acceptable. - all household (re-)construction is in accordance with safe building practices and standards. - all household (re-)construction demonstrate involvement of the affected population and/or are culturally acceptable by the affected population.

title.narrative: Hygiene promotion
WSH-I1: Number of people having regular access to soap to meet hygienic needs

description.narrative: Regular and timely access: 250g soap/p/m for personal hygiene, 200g soap/p/month for laundry. This includes hygiene/dignity kits. Access may be in-kind or though voucher distribution or through unconditional restricted cash to enable beneficiary to buy soap (without compromising access to other basic needs). Distributed items need to be culturally acceptable i.e. take into account local practice and expectations.

title.narrative: Short-term livelihood support
FSC-I1: Number of people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihoods assets

description.narrative: Resources that enable people to protect and rebuild their livelihood assets include seeds, livestock, tools, business grant, etc. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, restricted cash) and combination thereof to support, protect and enable the restoration/protection/access of/to livelihood assets.

title.narrative: Solid waste management
WSH-I5: Number of people living in settlements with a functional solid waste management system

description.narrative: Solid waste of all households of the settlements as well as commercial waste is removed stored safely and removed regularly with equipment and frequency according to standards (Sphere). Risk of solid waste pollution of environment is kept to a minimum. Medical waste is managed separately according to standards to minimize risk. System implies: planning and implementation in consultation with affected populations and relevant authorities, taking into account refuse type and quantity, incl. medical, burial, market etc; adequate disposal with minimum risk; attention to staff welfare.

title.narrative: Excreta disposal
WSH-I2: Number of people having access to dignified, safe, clean and functional excreta disposal facilities

description.narrative: Access: ratio (user/facility) of 1 toilet for a max. 20 people, distance < 50 metres from dwellings, or as locally agreed. Clean: regular cleaning and maintenance for public facilities. Dignified: Use of toilets respect cultural preference and is arranged by household(s) and/or segregated by sex. Unsafe facilities: unstable (unlined) pits with risk of collapse, pits accessible to vectors, pits contaminating water tables and poorly sited facilities which expose women and girls to attacks, especially at night. Functional facility: fully constructed, in working order and properly maintained, of a type and in a location acceptable to intended users, with hand washing facilities and anal cleansing material.

description.narrative: Distribution of Non-Food Items. All household materials excluding those that fall under hygiene/dignity kits or direct shelter items. Also excludes unrestricted cash, which is to be put under indicator CSH-I1 or CSH-I2. However, if cash is provided for the purpose of buying household items, it should be put under this indicator (i.e. restricted cash).

Burundi KfW Improvement access to SRH through RBF Phase II

description.narrative: Le groupe cible du programme est la population des provinces de Gitega, Muramvya et Mwaro regroupant environ 1,7 millions d’habitants et particulièrement les femmes en âge de procréation et les enfants de moins de 5 ans ainsi que les jeunes. Le premier niveau d’intervention du programme est le niveau décentralisé le plus bas des services de santé, à savoir les ASC qui sont regroupés en GASC et les FOSA au nombre de 75 dans la province de GITEGA dont 65 CDS (60 avec contrat principal et 5 contrats secondaires) et 10 hôpitaux (7 avec contrat principal et 3 contrats secondaires), 29 dans la province de MURAMVYA dont 27 CDS (24 avec contrat principal et 3 contrat secondaire) et 2 hôpitaux (avec contrat principal) et 28 dans la province de MWARO dont 26 CDS et 2 hôpitaux.

Les évènements de l’année 2015, ont fragilisé le Burundi dans plusieurs domaines de la vie du pays sur le plan interne et externe notamment dans ses relations de coopération internationale avec d’autres pays et la communauté internationale . Ainsi, plusieurs pays ont suspendu les appuis directs au gouvernement du Burundi. Dans le même cadre , le gouvernement allemand a suspendu en parti ses activités dans le pays jusqu'à nouvel ordre. Cependant, dans le souci de sauvegarder les acquis dans le système de santé burundais, le gouvernement allemand a décidé d’appuyer ce système par l’intermédiaire de l’Organisation non-gouvernementale (ONG) Cordaid (Bénéficiaire), pour améliorer la situation de la population la plus démunie, à travers un projet intitulé « Renforcement de la santé sexuelle et reproductive à travers le Financement basé sur la performance. La promière phase de ce projet d'un budget de 5 millions d'euros, a durée 2 ans, et a commencé le 31 décembre 2017 pour prendre fin le 28 Février 2020. La deuxième phase va durer 3 ans allant du 9 Avril 2020 au 31 mars 2023 et couvre trois provinces sanitaires ( Gitega, Muramvya et Mwaro).

L’objectif général du projet est de contribuer à l’amélioration de la santé de la population burundaise, notamment des femmes, des nouveau-nés, des enfants et des jeunes dans les provinces de Gitega, Muramvya et Mwaro. L’objectif spécifique du programme est de contribuer à l’augmentation des services de santé de base de bonne qualité notamment en matière de santé reproductive (SR) à travers l’approche de Financement Basé sur la Performance (FBP) dans les provinces de Gitega, Muramvya et Mwaro.

title.narrative: Creating Access for Inclusive Peace Processes in Afghanistan

description.narrative: Afghanistan has suffered from over four decades of war. While there was a measure of progress during the last 18 years, there are widespread concerns that that women’s rights and other social gains could be reversed with the potential return of the Taliban to the political order. The absence of women in formal peace negotiations has heightened these concerns. To protect women and girls’ rights and the gains achieved, women and civil society have to be capacitated to strategically and meaningfully contribute to the peace processes and to demonstrate that women and girls’ rights and a rights-based agenda has a broad based support in Afghan society. Likewise, more diversified perspectives on all matters concerning the peace talks will lead to stronger peace outcomes. They will, in particular, have to be prepared to make a case within an Islamic framework to counter traditional and religious groups supporting regressive gender norms.
Improved institutional rights and inclusive participation of women and girls in the Afghan peace processes.

The program will be implemented in Afghanistan, in close collaboration with the Afghan Women’s Network. Women, men and civil society actors from throughout the country, particularly conflict affected areas, will be engaged through the selection of the Advisory Committee, the Core Group, the Circle of Allies, consultations and other activities devised by the Advisory Committee. It will also support the capacity of this group to engage in peacemaking opportunities inside and outside Afghanistan, including Qatar, Norway and other locations where Afghan peace related initiatives are convened.

description.narrative: 31620 primary beneficiaries, mainly women; 19190 other direct beneficiaries

Impact: Women’s mobilization and advocacy at local, district, provincial and national levels contributes to creating a safer, more just and more peaceful Afghanistan for all
Objective 1: Enhance existing and new PWNs' capacity to collect and use evidence for advocacy purposes, establishing new PWNs in 19 provinces and supporting all 34 PWNs to conduct research and participatory analysis on relevant policy issues.
Objective 2: Stimulate systematic responsiveness and accountability from security, justice and governance duty-bearers and power-holders on the basis of effective mobilization and advocacy by women.
Objective 3: Promote inclusion of women’s voices in Afghan peace processes at all levels.

Since the removal of the Taliban in 2001 and the establishment of the current republic, Afghan women have mobilized to successfully demand widespread changes intended to improve gender equality and women’s empowerment. Gains achieved by women under the Government of the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan (GoIRA) are not insubstantial, yet women continue to face discrimination and human rights abuses. Patriarchal social norms and institutionalized exclusion combine to prevent women and girls from accessing the services they are entitled to as citizens; this is especially true of the security and justice services they need to access protection from pervasive (sexual- and) gender-based violence, or (S)GBV, or for justice when such violence occurs. Likewise, women are generally excluded from public decision-making, including meaningful contribution to Afghanistan’s peace processes, from the local to the highest policy levels, and thereby prevented from helping to shape the country’s future.

title.narrative: Creating Opportunities to Earn and Improve Employability among Internally Displaced Persons and Returnees in Kandahar and Herat

description.narrative:
(M)SMEs below the age of 40 with growth potential;
Young IDPs and Returnees;

The proposed action – implemented through a consortium constituting the Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC) and Cordaid – seeks to create jobs and income earning opportunities for displaced people and vulnerable host communities in Afghanistan, through private sector growth. It aims to build on and complement the Government of Afghanistan’s flagship EZ-Kar programme, a five-year project funded by the World Bank, the European Union, and other donors which aims to “strengthen the enabling environment for economic opportunities in cities where there is a high influx of displaced people”.
More specifically, the proposed action is designed to complement EZ-Kar’s Component 2.2, which seeks to improve the market-enabling infrastructure in urban centres. This action will capitalise on the enhanced business environment created by EZ-Kar to increase the number of jobs created by local businesses, and, crucially, ensure that displaced populations benefit from these new job opportunities. This action therefore includes two main pillars: on the one hand, supporting micro, small and medium enterprise (MSMEs) who benefit from EZ-Kar’s enhanced business environment to further grow their business and create jobs; on the other hand, supporting youth from displaced and vulnerable host community families living in those areas to secure and retain decent jobs in these MSMEs.

Performance Based Financing in Borana zone 2020-2022

description.narrative: A total of 488.556 people living in the catchment area of (maximum) 25 targeted Health Facilities (or a total of 793,365 people, if we take the total catchment population of the two hospitals included in Phase II) in the 8 project Woredas will benefit from the project implementation.

Ethiopia has made steady improvements towards achieving its main health goals. There is good progress in reducing mortality and morbidity among children and women. Over the last two decades, the under-five mortality rate declined from 166 deaths per 100,000 live births in 2000 to 67 in 2016 and infant mortality rate (IMR) declined from 97 deaths per 100,000 live births in 2000 to 48 deaths per 100,000 live births in 2016. Between 2000 and 2016, Contraceptive Prevalence Rate increased from 8 percent to 36 percent; births attended by skilled attendants increased from 6 percent to 28 percent and maternal mortality (although still high) declined from 871 maternal deaths per 100 000 live births in 2000 to 412 in 2016. However, Ethiopia remains one of the poorest countries in the world with lagging indicators in maternal and child health, especially neonatal mortality. Equitable access to basic services is a concern, while quality of services and readiness of facilities to provide quality services is a major hindrance to Universal Health Coverage (UHC). Financial protection from serious illness remains inadequate and is one of the most challenging agendas for the next decades.
In Ethiopia, Cordaid started to showcase PBF in the arid and pastoralist Borana zone. After a participatory design process of six months, the project officially started on May 1st, 2015. Stakeholders involved in the design of the PBF project in Borana were among others the Oromia Regional Health Bureau (ORHB), the Borana Zonal Health Department (ZHD) and 4 Woreda (district) Health Offices. Phase I of the PBF project ended on the 30th of June 2018. Since the results were positive, and contributed to an increase in both the utilisation and the quality of health care services, the Borana ZHD and Cordaid jointly designed Phase II: scaling up from 4 to 8 woredas, from 9 to 25 health facilities and from a catchment population of 125,918 to a population of 488,556. Phase II started in July 2018 and will end by December 2019. Both phases are supported by Cordaid own funding.

Improved availability and accessibility of good quality healthcare at primary and secondary level in the Borana Zone (Oromia Region, Ethiopia), and a stronger health system at large, which supports the progressive realization of Universal Health Coverage (SDG 3.8) in this geographical area.” transparency

title.narrative: Individual household shelter
SHL-I1: Number of people having access to basic, safe and dignified shelters solutions

description.narrative: Basic, safe and dignified: - affected individuals have an minimum covered floor area of 3.5m2 per person. - all shelter solutions and materials meet locally agreed technical and performance standards and are culturally acceptable. - all household (re-)construction is in accordance with safe building practices and standards. - all household (re-)construction demonstrate involvement of the affected population and/or are culturally acceptable by the affected population.

title.narrative: Unconditional and unrestricted cash
CSH-I1: Number of people benefitting from unconditional and unrestricted cash transfers

description.narrative: Unconditional transfers are provided to beneficiaries without the recipient having to do anything in return in order to receive the assistance . Unrestricted transfers can be used entirely as the recipient chooses i.e. there are no restrictions on how the transfer is spent (Definitions of CALP). It can be delivered e.g. through local banks, shops, traders, local money transfer companies, remittance companies and post offices in either one or several instalments.

title.narrative: Prevention and response to violence
PRO-I1: Number of persons reached by the implementation of specific prevention measures

description.narrative:
1) Preventive measure must be built on a thorough analysis of the risks and should - as much as possible - be designed to provide concrete changes in the short/medium term. Changes must be measured in the course of the action. Preventive measure should focus on the increased risks resulting from the crisis, rather than more structural issues. 2) Use the activity description field to describe what measures are foreseen (sensitisation, infrastructure, etc.).3) Number of persons reached by prevention measures must be disaggregated by age and sex at reporting stage.4) If action also includes response activities, please add a custom indicator to reflect this.
Please note that prevention of GBV is captured under PRO-I11.

title.narrative: Child Protection
PRO-I15: Number of children that received support specified to their needs

description.narrative: 1) This indicator covers response to children (girls and boys under 18). 2) Appropriate response is defined as the provision of comprehensive services/assistance based on a thorough analysis of the risks faced by persons. The protection outcome of the response must be well defined. Relevant SOPs (including functional Referral Mechanism) should be followed. 3) Use the activity description field to to describe what services (medical, MHPSS, legal, security, etc.), as well as SOPs are in place. Activities can include psychosocial support to children, Child Friendly Spaces and support to parents to fulfill their protection responsibilities towards their children.

description.narrative: For its 6th phase the The focus of the CARJR remains to save lives, respect basic rights and preserve human dignity. This is leading by our humanitarian mandate to go there were the needs are. In the CAR the needs are everywhere, due to the history of the CAR, but the needs and gaps have been assessed to see where the CARJR could fulfil its objective best, and have the most impact. Cordaid will be in Ouham-Pendé (Koui, Ngaoundaye, Bocaranga) and Mbomou (bangassou) implementing activities on WASH and FSL. These sub-prefectures have the highest needs in the prefecture, and the focus will be on newly accessible return areas, including local partners and more national actors and state services to include then further in the response, initiating a humanitarian capacity strengthening process, which is part of phasing out of the areas.
Lives saving and resilience strengthening of conflict affected people in the Ouham-Pendé and Mbomou prefectures in CAR

title.narrative: Water Supply
WSH-I4: Number of people having access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use

description.narrative: Access: maximum distance to water point 500m, queuing time less than 15min, filling time maximum 3 min/20 litres or as locally agreed. Water access should be during the whole period of implementation unless action is mostly related to building the local water delivery capacity. Sufficient: covering basic needs, i.e. 7.5-15 l/p/d or as locally agreed. Safe: 1) low risk of faecal contamination, 2) No faecal coliforms detectable in any 100-ml sample, 3) For piped water supplies, or for all water supplies at times of risk or presence of diarrhoea epidemic, water is treated with a disinfectant to achieve free chlorine residual at the tap of 0.5 mg per litre and turbidity is below 5 NTU, 4) If for a short period, water which is contaminated chemically or radiologically is used, no (significant probability of) negative health effect is (likely to be) detected. Domestic use: drinking, cooking and personal hygiene (incl. laundry)

title.narrative: Hygiene promotion (Awareness)
WSH-I6: Number of people reached with hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities

description.narrative: Hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities. Could be training, campaigns, radio broadcasts, flyers etc. Excludes the distribution of Hygiene/dignity kits that should be covered under WHS-I1.

title.narrative: Hygiene promotion
WSH-I1: Number of people having regular access to soap to meet hygienic needs

description.narrative: Regular and timely access: 250g soap/p/m for personal hygiene, 200g soap/p/month for laundry. This includes hygiene/dignity kits. Access may be in-kind or though voucher distribution or through unconditional restricted cash to enable beneficiary to buy soap (without compromising access to other basic needs). Distributed items need to be culturally acceptable i.e. take into account local practice and expectations.

title.narrative: Short-term livelihood support
FSC-I1: Number of people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihoods assets

description.narrative: Resources that enable people to protect and rebuild their livelihood assets include seeds, livestock, tools, business grant, etc. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, restricted cash) and combination thereof to support, protect and enable the restoration/protection/access of/to livelihood assets.

title.narrative: Excreta disposal
WSH-I2: Number of people having access to dignified, safe, clean and functional excreta disposal facilities

description.narrative: Access: ratio (user/facility) of 1 toilet for a max. 20 people, distance < 50 metres from dwellings, or as locally agreed. Clean: regular cleaning and maintenance for public facilities. Dignified: Use of toilets respect cultural preference and is arranged by household(s) and/or segregated by sex. Unsafe facilities: unstable (unlined) pits with risk of collapse, pits accessible to vectors, pits contaminating water tables and poorly sited facilities which expose women and girls to attacks, especially at night. Functional facility: fully constructed, in working order and properly maintained, of a type and in a location acceptable to intended users, with hand washing facilities and anal cleansing material.

CAR Joint Response 6 – Lead Budget (Covid-19)

description.narrative: Overall there is no significant change in specific target groups from CARJR5 to the next phases. The aim is still to reach the most vulnerable affected persons (women, children, disabled, elderly and otherwise vulnerable people. This includes IDPs, returnees and host communities. Due to the inclusion of two new prefectures, there will be a clear new geographical group of affected people targeted with the proposed intervention. There will be a specific focus on reaching women and girls during this next phases. For the next phase, the CARJR plans to reached 97,082 affected people with the intervention (including overlap of 25,953 people).

The focus of the CARJR remains to Save lives, respect basic rights and preserve human dignity. This is leading by our humanitarian mandate to go there were the needs are. In the CAR the needs are everywhere, due to the history of the CAR, but the needs and gaps have been assessed to see where the CARJR could fulfil its objective best, and have the most impact. Based on the analysis the JR is expanding its activities to the latter 2 prefectures. The strategy of the JR partners is to slowly shift focus from Ouham and Ouham Pendé to Mbomou and NanaGribizi (Kaga-Bandoro), while not forgetting that needs are still existing in the Ouhams as well.
The focus of the CARJR remains to Save lives, respect basic rights and preserve human dignity. This is leading by our humanitarian mandate to go there were the needs are.

title.narrative: Yemen Joint Response 2020-2021

description.narrative: Based up selection criteria following cluster guidelines, the Health Facilities will be selected for rehabilitation. Cordaid/ Yamaan will target areas where facilities are either lacking or inadequate, where large number of IPDs have arrived. For the distribution of cash for NCD, the diseases will be selected according to needs assessment. Cordaid/ Yamaan will obtain a list of patients from SCMCHA and MoPHP and will then verify eligibility the beneficiaries. The patients selected for treatment with Sickle Cell Anemia & Thalassemia will also be selected in cooperation with SCMCHA and the Association of Sickle Cell Anemia and Thalassemia in Hodeidah, and it will include patients in most need and who need blood transfusion. Additionally, the association will be strengthened as well.

The humanitarian crisis in Yemen remains the worst in the world and over four years of intense conflict, as well as severe economic decline coupled with recent famine and cholera, has put millions of people at risk. An estimated 80 per cent of the population – 24 million people – require some form of humanitarian or protection assistance (HNO 2019). Within the most affected areas are Cordaid/ Yamaan’s targeted locations for the YRJ 2020: Hudaidah (lHali, Alhawk and Bait AlFageeh) and Sana’a (Maeen, Sabeen and Bani Hareth). Both governorates are in great need of assistance: Hudaidah continues to be target for many air strikes since the beginning of the year, driving new and secondary displacement, depleting coping mechanisms of the affected population, aggravating humanitarian conditions. Currently Hudaydah has 2.7 million people in need (61% in acute need) whilst in Sana’a 1.1 million people are in need (30% in acute need) .
The objectives of the project are to save lives through increasing access to basic health services

Projet la prise en charge du volet «violences basées sur le genre (VBG): prévention, sensibilisation et prise en charge communautaire

description.narrative: La République centrafricaine traverse une crise complexe et profonde aux conséquences humanitaires et de protection graves depuis plusieurs années. Ces conflits politico-militaires ont eu des conséquences dramatiques sur les populations en engendrant le déplacement massif des populations, la déstructuration de l’appareil étatique, des services sociaux de base et en mettant sous le contrôle des groupes armés plus de la moitié du territoire. On note aussi l’inaccessibilité aux services sociaux de base et l’impact socio-économique de la pandémie de la COVID-19 ont profondément érodé les capacités de survie physique et mentale de la population centrafricaine et causé une détérioration significative de leurs conditions de vie. Dans ce contexte, les femmes et les filles sont davantage exposées et vulnérables au moment de ces déplacements (déplacés internes, réfugiés, communautés hôtes), tout particulièrement aux violences sexuelles et elles ne disposent aucun service de SR/VBG et de prévention de la Covid-19. Face à cette situation, le Gouvernement de la République centrafricaine a sollicité et obtenu un financement de l’Association Internationale de développement (IDA) pour financer le secteur de la santé au titre du projet d’appui et de Renforcement du système de Santé (SENI) et a recruté des ONGI pour la Prise en charge du volet Violence Basée sur le Genre pour la réalisation des activités de prévention, sensibilisation et prise en charge communautaire. Cordaid a été retenu pour implémenter le projet dans les districts sanitaires d’Alindao et de Nola.

Les bénéficiaires sont constitués des populations de 3 formations sanitaires du district sanitaire d'Alindao que sont: CS de Poudjio, CS de Pavika et CS de Kongho. Les bénéficiaires sont constitués des filles, garçons, hommes et femmes des 3 formations sanitaires qui couvrent environs 88 563 habitants

title.narrative: MHPSS+ in Iraq and Syria

description.narrative: Due to decades of war, the massive destruction and the atrocities by warring factions (ISIL is an important but not the sole perpetrator), the needs on Mental Health and Psychosocial Support (MHPSS) both in Iraq and Syria are high. All ethnic, religious and tribal groups have suffered, but the last years - due to ISIL - minorities were hit the most. MHPSS is an emerging policy area. This responds to growing understanding of the prevalence of mental health conditions like anxiety and depression due to collective and individual trauma in fragile contexts. Those conditions also affect individual life courses and collective capacities to overcome fragility. MHPSS has the potential to support these collective capacities when it is strengthened by or integrated in a community approach, Primary Health Care and (S)GBV treatment. The treatment capabilities for MHPSS are lacking due to the erosion of health systems and to the stigma of MHPSS. The latter means that few healthcare professionals have been educated to provide MHPSS. The gap between the many needs and the small number of caregivers is called “treatment gap or “mental health gap”. This project builds upon the trackrecord of the successfull implementation of 5 projects so far that have been addressing MHPSS, often in combination with Primary Health Care (PHC). In Spring 2017, Cordaid started MHPSS with Memisa funding and continued in 2018 and 2019. The projects were complemented in 2018 and 2019 with OCHA and WHO funding. Since January 2019, Cordaid provides MH in the hospital of the city of Sinjar and PSS in a community center in the same city in a one-year project. Sinjar is infamous because it is the symbol of the evil ISIL committed and where they committed genocide, rape and sexual slavery to the Yezidi people. The collective trauma of the slowly returning Yezidis is immense. Because of similar context and needs in Syria Cordaid will expand its activities to health care in Aleppo. Cordaid will add MHPSS to one Health Facility in the city of Aleppo that was reconstructed earlier by the Humanitarian Aid Unit of Cordaid. This will benefit inhabitants of a very traumatized region. The expansion to Syria will increase Cord-aids profile in Syria among donors and policy makers too.
unstable communities

title.narrative: Gender based violence (Prevention, response, other)
PRO-I12: Number of survivors who receive an appropriate response to GBV

description.narrative:
1) This indicator covers response to survivors of GBV (women, men, girls and boys).2) Appropriate response is defined as the provision of comprehensive services/assistance based on a thorough analysis of the risks faced by persons. The protection outcome of the response must be well defined. Relevant SOPs (including functional Referral Mechanism) should be followed. 3) Use the activity description field to describe what services (medical, MHPSS, legal, security, etc.), as well as SOPs in place.4) Number of persons must be disaggregated by age and sex at reporting stage.5) If action also includes prevention activities, please add a custom indicator to reflect this.
In case it concerns medical care to GBV survivors, please capture this under HEA-I8.

title.narrative: Prevention and response to COVID-19 pandemic related to WASH

Selam Ahun! “Peace Now”

description.narrative:
- Women and men in Addis Ababa and other regions of Ethiopia - Direct- 2364 - Indirect- 80,000 and communities in 9 Kebelles of Yabello woreda.
The direct beneficiaries are Women In Oromia region, In Yabello woreda where there is an existing conflict. And also, Women in Addis Ababa and other regions who will be reached through free legal aid services and most vulnerable women who will be provided with survivors' fund for transportation and court fees. The Indirect beneficiaries are Family numbers of beneficiaries, youth, men, and other communities in 9 Kebeles of Yabello Woreda in Oromia region.

In Ethiopia, which has a highly diverse population, conflict threatens to challenge peaceful coexistence and the stability of the country in which over 51% are women. Since ethnic and religious violence has caused instability in most of the country. Disunity and intolerance are on the rise. The crisis has led to the destruction of houses and community infrastructure, disruption of livelihoods leading to massive displacement. If left unchecked, the conflict will drive the country into deeper poverty and fragility. In this, the impact on society will be detrimental and women will lose the most, as they become prime target for political violence. They will not only suffer from increased gender-based violence but also undergo traumatic experience during conflict-induced displacement.
Access to justice has formally been recognized as an important constitutional and policy issue in Ethiopia. But the implementation has been inconsistent in serving women, children, and other vulnerable groups. The formal law enforcement and customary dispute resolution mechanism are often male dominated in that women are largely excluded from key decision-making process. Besides, there are some cultures and practices that still allow harmful and discriminatory practices against women.
Women’s justice needs and experiences may, however, be different from men due to higher levels of poverty and power dynamics in the family and community. Building on the UNDP’s definition of access to justice, the mapping report on non-conflict settings defines women’s access to justice as: “Access by women, in particular, from poor and disadvantaged groups, to fair, effective, affordable and accountable mechanisms, for the protection of rights, control of abuse of power, and resolution of conflicts. This includes the ability of women to seek and obtain a fair and just remedy through formal and informal justice systems and the ability to influence and participate in law-making processes and institutions.”
Long before formal justice system is introduced, Ethiopia had traditional institutional mechanisms as well as cultural resources to uphold the values of peace, tolerance, solidarity, and respect for, and of, one another. These structures were responsible for “peace education, confidence-building, conflict prevention and conflict resolution”.
These mechanisms were effective in managing conflicts caused by dispute over land, chieftaincy, and matrimonial fallouts and their decisions were binding on all parties. The role of the chiefs, elders, family heads and others, who take leadership is highly regarded. Women have specific role especially on identifying conflict risks and take part in mediation as their male counterparts, but their role did not come out strongly to complement other conflict resolution mechanisms. The project will closely work with traditional justice structure to strengthen their role in conflict management and peace building.
Traditional institutions where women in Oromia region play significant roles in conflict resolution and protection of their rights called “Siqee”, these groups do not have formal legal body but will be closely supported by Oromia region culture and tourism affairs office. The traditional community governance system called “Gadaa” system provides the women with their own institutional arrangement in which the Oromo women participate in the socio-cultural activities that protect their rights. These institutions helped the women to mobilize themselves for various causes among which that harm their group identity. They also clearly showed the place women had in the religious, social, and cultural settings of the Oromo people.
Ethiopian women play a central role in the social domain, but their voices and perspectives are very limited heard and shared in the political domain. Even though there is now a 50% representation in the ministerial cabinet, they have limited leadership roles in the lower and middle level public administration and informal justice structure so as to influence the agenda towards peace in the country.
Women in Ethiopian also face a problem in getting access and utility to the formal justice sector. Even the situation is getting worse after the outbreak of COVID 19. The United Nation in its May, 2020 assessment report in Ethiopia describes that " In times of crisis such as an outbreak, women and girls may be at higher risk, for example, of intimate partner violence and other forms of domestic violence due to heightened tensions in the household. They also face increased risk of other forms of gender-based violence including sexual exploitation and abuse."1 . (United Nations Ethiopia, One UN assessment on Socio economic Impact of COVID 19 in Ethiopia , May 2020).Therefore, it is timely and necessary working towards enhancing access and utility to justice sector for women and girls.
Using the recent opening up of the government for CSOs to be engaged in peacebuilding as a window of opportunity, this project plans to contribute to women becoming more involved in peacebuilding at the community as well as regional level women’s initiatives in their localities will play a critical role in national discourses on peacebuilding, tolerance and nationhood following the Women, Peace and Security agenda. The project will assess capacity gap and provide specific support to build the capacity of informal justice structure in order to make their services more effective in conflict resolution and peace building.
In addition, Cordaid Ethiopia plans to work in partnership with the Ministry of Peace, Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) and local administration. The entry point at the local level will be through informal traditional justice mechanism. Such institutions act as vehicles for socialization and support, which reaches both women and youth

This project primarily aims to improve and sustain protection of women’s right and their involvement on conflict prevention and increase women’s access and utility of the formal and informal justice structure.

title.narrative: Water Supply
WSH-I4: Number of people having access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use

description.narrative: Access: maximum distance to water point 500m, queuing time less than 15min, filling time maximum 3 min/20 litres or as locally agreed. Water access should be during the whole period of implementation unless action is mostly related to building the local water delivery capacity. Sufficient: covering basic needs, i.e. 7.5-15 l/p/d or as locally agreed. Safe: 1) low risk of faecal contamination, 2) No faecal coliforms detectable in any 100-ml sample, 3) For piped water supplies, or for all water supplies at times of risk or presence of diarrhoea epidemic, water is treated with a disinfectant to achieve free chlorine residual at the tap of 0.5 mg per litre and turbidity is below 5 NTU, 4) If for a short period, water which is contaminated chemically or radiologically is used, no (significant probability of) negative health effect is (likely to be) detected. Domestic use: drinking, cooking and personal hygiene (incl. laundry)

title.narrative: Hygiene promotion (Awareness)

description.narrative: Hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities. Could be training, campaigns, radio broadcasts, flyers etc. Excludes the distribution of Hygiene/dignity kits that should be covered under WHS-I1.

title.narrative: Short-term livelihood support
FSC-I1: Number of people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihoods assets

description.narrative: Resources that enable people to protect and rebuild their livelihood assets include seeds, livestock, tools, business grant, etc. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, restricted cash) and combination thereof to support, protect and enable the restoration/protection/access of/to livelihood assets.

title.narrative: Excreta disposal
WSH-I2: Number of people having access to dignified, safe, clean and functional excreta disposal facilities

description.narrative: Access: ratio (user/facility) of 1 toilet for a max. 20 people, distance < 50 metres from dwellings, or as locally agreed. Clean: regular cleaning and maintenance for public facilities. Dignified: Use of toilets respect cultural preference and is arranged by household(s) and/or segregated by sex. Unsafe facilities: unstable (unlined) pits with risk of collapse, pits accessible to vectors, pits contaminating water tables and poorly sited facilities which expose women and girls to attacks, especially at night. Functional facility: fully constructed, in working order and properly maintained, of a type and in a location acceptable to intended users, with hand washing facilities and anal cleansing material.

Project SENI VBG Shanga Mbaéré

description.narrative: La République centrafricaine traverse une crise complexe et profonde aux conséquences humanitaires et de protection graves depuis plusieurs années. Ces conflits politico-militaires ont eu des conséquences dramatiques sur les populations en engendrant le déplacement massif des populations, la déstructuration de l’appareil étatique, des services sociaux de base et en mettant sous le contrôle des groupes armés plus de la moitié du territoire. On note aussi l’inaccessibilité aux services sociaux de base et l’impact socio-économique de la pandémie de la COVID-19 ont profondément érodé les capacités de survie physique et mentale de la population centrafricaine et causé une détérioration significative de leurs conditions de vie. Dans ce contexte, les femmes et les filles sont davantage exposées et vulnérables au moment de ces déplacements (déplacés internes, réfugiés, communautés hôtes), tout particulièrement aux violences sexuelles et elles ne disposent aucun service de SR/VBG et de prévention de la Covid-19. Face à cette situation, le Gouvernement de la République centrafricaine a sollicité et obtenu un financement de l’Association Internationale de développement (IDA) pour financer le secteur de la santé au titre du projet d’appui et de Renforcement du système de Santé (SENI) et a recruté des ONGI pour la Prise en charge du volet Violence Basée sur le Genre pour la réalisation des activités de prévention, sensibilisation et prise en charge communautaire. Cordaid a été retenu pour implémenter le projet dans les districts sanitaires d’Alindao et de Nola.

Les bénéficiaires sont constitués des populations de 4 formations sanitaires du district sanitaire de Nola que sont: Belemboké, Sao, Mambéré et Zend. Les bénéficiaires sont constitués des filles, garçons, hommes et femmes des 4 formations sanitaires qui couvrent environs 134 446 habitants.

description.narrative: 1) Preventive measure must be built on a thorough analysis of the risks and should - as much as possible - be designed to provide concrete changes in the short/medium term. Changes must be measured in the course of the action. Preventive measure should focus on the increased risks resulting from the crisis, rather than more structural issues. 2) Use the activity description field to to describe what measures are foreseen (sensitisation, infrastructure, etc.).3) Number of persons reached by prevention measures must be disaggregated by age and sex at reporting stage.4) If action also includes response activities, please add a custom indicator to reflect this.

Projet pilote de Financement basé sur la performance au niveau communautaire dans les provinces du Nord et du Sud Kivu (COVID)

description.narrative: Renforcer la dynamique communautaire à travers les membres des CODESA dans la lutte de la propagation de Covid-19 dans les milieux Urbain et Rural, Ainsi d’aider les communautés à être plus résilientes vis-à-vis de cette pandémie Covid-19

Since the outbreak of Coronavirus (COVID-19) in Wuhan, China, the global public health threat posed by COVID-19 is high, with more than 700,000 reported cases worldwide. The DRC Ministry of Health confirmed the first case of COVID-19 in the DRC on March 10, 2020. The DRC President decided enhanced screening, quarantine measures and movement restriction to reduce the spread of COVID-19, along with recommended basic protective measures (hand-washing and social distancing). However, DRC is a vast country, with more than 80 million inhabitants leaving in dire conditions. The health system is weak and will not be able to handle a major health crisis. Many people don’t have access to clean water, stay together in small spaces and live from hand-to-mouth. In addition, a health crisis could rapidly turn into a social crisis, as the informal sector accounts for more than 80% of the economy. Faced with the spread of this epidemic in DRC, it is urgent to sensitize populations to raise awareness of the danger posed by this disease and to respect the recommendations of the health authorities for proper prevention against the pandemic. Note that Covid-19 is already declared in four regions of the DRC, in particular: the city province of Kinshasa, the cities of Goma and Bukavu respectively two neigh boring provinces North and South Kivu and in the city of Ituri in Province of Bunia. At present the risks are very high and community interventions are very urgent.

Total beneficiaries: 1272 Women: 240 Children: 150 Men: 600 Elderly: 150 Disabled: Others (please specify): 132 Leaders Communautaires, religieux et infirmiers des centres de santé et equipes des DPS et BCZS

Corona prevention and preparedness border provinces of Afghanistan

description.narrative: Afghanistan battling the prolong armed conflict, injustice and poverty (54.5% people are below poverty line ) now facing the Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), which is an infectious disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus. The disease was first identified in 2019 in Wuhan, China, and has since spread globally, resulting in the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic and found more than 200,000 people infected globally and killed more than 6,000 people ( as of 18-March-2020). The World Health Organization (WHO) declared the 2019–20 coronavirus outbreak a pandemic and a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC). Evidence of local transmission of the disease has been found in many countries. Afghanistan has a very poor health system in the world and has a very low Capacity. In the counter the health expenditure is US$ 905 per capita while the health ministry allocated US$ 58 per capita. More than 4 million of Afghan refugees are living in Iran and Pakistan. Iran was found the second most infected country in Asia after china, there are movement of refugees and other Afghan civilian to and from Iran, the COVID-19 cases has been detected in the country with 22 positive cases (as of 18-Marc-2020). The people in the country has concern on the reported cases because of the capacity of the government and do believe that the cases are much higher which may create another disaster in the country and may affect the whole region.
Awareness Sessions for the prevention of COVID-19 Soap Distribution Increasing Government capacity for conducting test Assisting most vulnerable people with cash for food
General population with focus on COVID-19 positive cases.

Corona prevention and preparedness in South Sudan

description.narrative: Health workers,All men, women and children living in high risk areas and are exposed to COVID-19 risks

In December 2019, the world saw the emergency of a virus that causes pneumonia in humans, which has a high probability of resulting in complications that include acute respiratory distress syndrome and death in an estimated 0.2% to 5% of cases. Corona virus disease 2019 (COVID-2019) is caused by a virus endemic in wild animals that has adapted itself to infect humans. The world health Organization (WHO) declared the 2019 outbreak of the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV), which is now officially named SARS-CoV-2, a global health emergency on 20th Jan 2020. Currently there is no effective antivirals against the virus. The virus is genetically similar to the 2003 Severe acute respiratory syndrome – related coronavirus (SARS) and shares many disease features with influenza virus infections. The COVID-19 virus is a novel (new) coronavirus first identified in Wuhan, China. Since its discovery, its geographic distribution continues to evolve. Cases have been reported in more than 100 countries, sustained person-to-person transmission is now suspected in several countries in addition to China
Globally, 339,710 cases with 14704 deaths and 99014 recovered cases have been reported and these figures keep changing daily due to the rapid spread associated with the virus. In Africa, 739 confirmed cases with 20 deaths already report (WHO sitrep #62). Regionally, South Sudan remains the only country in the sub-Saharan east Africa without confirmed case of COVID-19 virus. All the countries that neighbour South Sudan has confirmed cases of COVID-19. To-date Uganda has already confirmed Nine cases, Kenya has 16 confirmed cases, Ethiopia with 9 confirmed cases, DRC with 23 cases, Sudan has reported one confirmed case and in all the countries mentioned, incidence rates keep soaring up each and every day. South Sudan remains fragile and it is just a matter of when not if before a case is confirmed in the nation. Due to travel, trade and social linkages, the potential risk of importing the virus to South Sudan remains very high and likely and it is almost inevitable that it will reach South Sudan.
South Sudan is already facing food insecurity, high malnutrition rates and poor health care services. With already the dire state of the country, the virus will cause more devastation if it spreads to the nation. As a measure to prevent the epidemic, the government of South Sudan put up measures however, these measures may not be adhered by the local population because of limited information and awareness about the disease. As result, we propose to build on our extensive hygiene promotion activities to raise awareness and sensitize the people of South Sudan on preventative measures against the spread and control of the epidemic to stop any incidence of the epidemic from occurring and or minimize/reduce the prevalence when identified in South Sudan.

The project will integrate risk communication messaging and health promotion among the South Sudanese on COVID 19 and support health system in infection prevention and control mechanism aimed at preventive the causative agent of COVID 19 and also support MoH to undertake health education and awareness including supporting integrated disease surveillance and reporting for Covid 19

Youth-led COVID-19 Response (YCR)

description.narrative: 1. Increased heath awareness; targets groups have the necessary knowledge, skills and motivation to protect themselves from COVID-19. 2. Health Systems Strengthening (HSS); public Health Centers and Village Health Teams in West Nile and Eastern Uganda with good mental health and well equipped with Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) to effectively handle COVID -19 cases. This will support the WHO’s HSS building blocks on service delivery and health work force. 3. Increased access to life saving services: refugees and host community members and selected vulnerable groups with increased access to safe water storage facility and soap to meet hygienic needs in response to COVID 19. PLWHA with access to ARVs. 4. Increase access to SRHR services: increased access to contraceptives and family planning consultation and services. 5. Well-coordinated CSOs supporting MoH to contain COVID-19 in West Nile and Eastern Uganda by

COVID 19 has become a global pandemic globally. More than 500,000 people have been contracted with the virus in the whole world. Over 23293 COVID-19 related deaths have been confirmed globally as of 27th/3/2020 and these are on the rise each passing minute. Life as it is known, has been altered causing a break down in major health systems even among countries with very reliable health structures like in the USA, Canada and China among others. Uganda registered her first case of corona virus 22/3/2020 which has risen to 18 to date 27/3/2020 The government of Uganda through the Ministry of health has issued guidelines and measures to respond to the pandemic; aimed at containment of the existing cases and prevention of farther spread of the virus. However, there has been a weakness in adhering to total quarantine and self-isolation guidelines hence increasing the risk of farther spread of COVID 19. There still exists inadequate awareness and appreciation of the threat among the general population. This is even worse in refugee settlements and their host communities in West Nile as well as the most rural districts of Uganda like Kamuli district. These being cross boarder communities, the risk is even higher due to continued influx of refugees and travelers through local unofficial and unregulated border routes. Access to clean water and soap amongst some population in Uganda is still a huge challenge making it difficult to regularly was hands as a measure of preventing farther corona virus spread. More so most water access point like boreholes and wells are always crowded which is even worse for rural communities like Kamuli district and refugee settlements and host communities which makes social distancing unachievable. The COVID-19 cases are projected to increase even higher given that COIVD- 19 risky population that returned from mainly Dubai had already been in physical contact with the general population. Being a new virus, the Ugandan health care system is not prepared enough in terms of human resource, medical supplies, emergency response and crisis coordination. As such, there is great need for humanitarian aid Organisations like Cordaid to contribute to the concerted effort by government, WHO and other CSOs in responding to this pandemic. Problem statement The threat of spread of covid-19 is Uganda remains inevitable especially among vulnerable groups in both urban and rural areas. In the regard, the COVID-19 cases are projected to increase even higher given that COIVD- 19 risky population that returned from mainly Dubai had already been in physical contact with the general population. The government through the President and Ministry of Health has issued guidelines and measures to respond to the pandemic aimed at containment of the existing cases and prevention of farther spread of the virus. However, there has been a weakness in adhering to total quarantine and self-isolation guidelines hence increasing the risk of farther spread of COVID 19. There still exists inadequate awareness and appreciation of the threat among the general population. Equally, implementation of the national guidelines on personal hygiene including use of personal protective gears, hand washing at household level during the economic turn-down remains a challenge. Access to clean water, sanitizers and soap amongst some population in Uganda is still a huge challenge making it difficult to regularly wash hands as a measure of preventing further spread of virus. The existing water access points like boreholes and wells are always crowded which is even worse for rural communities like Kamuli district and refugee settlements and host communities maki.ng social distancing hardly achievable. The situation and threat of covid-19 is more feared among the in refugee settlements and their host communities in West Nile. The country is host over 1.4 million refugees, primarily from neighbouring South Sudan and the Democratic Republic of the Congo, which is the largest refugee population in Africa. These being cross boarder communities, the risk is even higher due to continued influx of refugees and travellers through local unofficial and unregulated border routes. According to assessment by UNHCR, there is growing anxiety and worry about the potential outbreak of the pandemic in these settlement https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/04/fears-uganda-coronavirus-outbreak-refugee-settlements-200406145749564.html
In addition, the COVID‑19 pandemic and its consequences are negatively affecting the availability of and access to sexual and reproductive health (SRH) services. As the government and development partners drive their energies to responding to COVID-19, there is increasing limited access to SRHR services as a result of several factors including; health workers and community members having difficulty getting to health centres in absence of public transport, lack of commodities caused by a disrupted supply chains, reduced activity of community-based distributors of contraceptives and SBCC/IEC messages over focusing on COVID 19. There is a very high likelihood that this will heighten SRH challenges such as unplanned pregnancies, SGBV and sexually transmitted infections among others.

The project targets to directly benefit:
1. Refugees in Pagirinya settlements in West Nile with awareness for all the 3 outcome areas 2. Host communities in West Nile will be prioritized during supply of basic hand washing facilities and sanitizers. 3. Most at risk populations in West Nile and Kamuli e.g child headed H/H, crowded homestead, elderly, People with Disabilities, People living with TB and HIV/AIDS for all the three-outcome areas.
YCR project will work through channels of and ultimately also benefit:
4. Youth peer educators 5. Village Health Teams (VHTs) these will be engaged as COVID -19Response Ambassadors (CORAs)

VODAN Fair data

description.narrative: MoHs, universities, knowledge institutions, Taskforces, public and private stakeholders in the health sector.

Undetected spread of the novel corona virus, COVID-19, is a threat to countries on the African continent with limited digitally connected health data. The lack of data from all geographies is a problem for the analysis of the global spread of COVID-19, how it spreads, the differentiated impact in different populations, its mutations and associations with treatment. Top-level connect of these data is essential to support the fight against the virus.
The 2014 Ebola crisis and subsequent crises has taught that it is critical to develop long-lasting and durable solutions to strengthen health systems in terms of capacities to prevent, respond and innovate based on scientific understanding. Global inclusiveness is critical in a connected world where people are mobile.

WASH for COVID-19 outbreak prevention

description.narrative: Overall objective: This project aims to strengthen resilience of refugees and host communities in Imvepi and Kyangwali refugee settlements to respond adequately in preventing and mitigating the spread of coronavirus. Immediate Objectives 1. Equip communities with knowledge to identify and refer community members suspected to have contracted coronavirus 2. Create opportunities to enhance nutrition and livelihoods for refugees 3. Empower refugee communities with knowledge that causes change in attitude and practice to prevent spread of coronavirus and other WASH related illnesses

This project is designed to benefit refugees of South Sudanese and Congolese origins. However, some of the planned interventions such as radio programs will benefit host communities as well because of the diverse nature of radio listeners.

While Uganda enjoys relative peace and stability within the great lakes’ region, the country neighbours Democratic Republic of Congo and South Sudan that continue to experience sporadic conflicts. As a result, Uganda is hosting refugees from South Sudan, DRC, Burundi, Somali and others. As of February 2020, the total number of refugees in Uganda has increased to 1,411,098 from 1,347,360 as of September 2019 implying that there is an average influx of 12,746 into the country every month where the majority are coming from SSD and DRC. Out of this, 61.9% are South Sudanese and 29% are Congolese. Since the beginning of 2020, many INGOs and NGOs have phased out their implementation due reduced donor funding yet demand for services in the refugee and host communities continues. Both Kyangwali and Imvepi refugee settlements offer home to over sixty thousand (60.000) refugees who live in congested homesteads with basic hygiene and sanitation. Following the global coronavirus pandemic, different countries have taken steps to prevent and mitigate the spread of this virus. The President of the Republic of Uganda directed closure of all schools and learning institutions, worship houses and places of mass convergence 20th March and has encouraged and called upon support from all the actors to ensure that preventive measures are put in place and adhered to. While the measures put in place may be feasible to implement in many areas of Uganda, they are difficult to adhere to for refugees living in camps and host communities. Many refugees find themselves living hand-to-mouth, meaning if they miss work for even one day, they are immediately unable to buy the commodities they need for survival. This leads to the prioritisation of expenditures for food – at the risk of less money being spent to acquire necessary sanitation goods and clean water. To make matters worse, the announcement of the arrival of COVID-19 has seen suppliers increase prices of sanitation items making it even more difficult for those with limited means (including refugees) to acquire them. Given the rate at which coronavirus is spreading, Cordaid Uganda finds it pertinent to implement emergency measures to prevent the spread of the virus in refugee settlements. This is because living conditions of refugees and the country’s poor healthcare system can result into a full-blown disaster in the country especially in overcrowded dwellings such as refugee settlements. This project is a direct response to the UNHCR Covid-19 response plan; according to this plan, UNHCR Uganda COVID Response plan - March 2020 final, refugees in Uganda have freedom of movement and as such settlement-based refugees can/will easily access the selected higher risk locations. With the confirmation of Coronavirus cases in DR Congo, Adjumani, Hoima, Arua, Kampala and other locations, the risk of importation of the Coronavirus into Imvepi and Kyangwali has become much higher than earlier anticipated.

Projet de prévention contre le coronavirus dans les districts sanitaires appuyés par Cordaid en RCA

description.narrative: Le déclanchement de l’épidémie du COVID-19 a commencé en décembre 2019 en Chine avec l’enregistrement de plusieurs cas. L’épidémie s’est propagée dans plusieurs pays de tous les continents. Des cas et décès ont été enregistrés et signalés dans plusieurs pays au début de l’année 2020. Le 14 Mars 2020, un cas exporté a été diagnostiqué à Bangui chez un patient de 74 ans en provenance de Milan via le Maroc entrainant ainsi le ministre de la santé à déclarer l’épidémie à corona virus en république centrafricaine. En RCA, pour faire face à la pandémie, le gouvernement à travers le MSP en collaboration avec ses partenaires a développé un plan de riposte en mettant en place des commissions (Coordination multisectorielle, surveillance et laboratoire, prise en charge des cas et prévention et lutte contre l’infection, communication et risque, engagement communautaire et mobilisation sociale, population, logistique et recherche scientifique). Ce plan de réponse pour une période de 12 mois est estimé à 128, 5 millions de dollars américains. Seulement, 6,5 millions de dollars grâce à la contribution de la Banque Mondiale et de l’OMS sont disponibles. Les activités planifiées seront plus concentrées à Bangui et le long du corridor RCA-Cameroun. Aucune activité n’est pour le moment prévue dans les provinces………… Certaines mesures gouvernementales ont été prises pour lutter contre le COVID-19. Il s’agit des fermetures des églises, des bars, boites de nuit et des établissements primaires, secondaires et universitaires et des écoles de formations, fermeture de l’espace aérien excepté les vols humanitaires, restriction des déplacements à l’intérieur du pays, interdiction des regroupements de plus de 15 personnes. En RCA, Cordaid travaille dans 9 sous bureaux. Les projets santé sont menées dans 6 sous bureaux (Alindao, Mobaye, Bangassou, Bouar, Berbérati et Bangassou) et aussi à Bangui. En dehors du dispositif de lavage des mains disponible dans les sous-bureaux, aucune autre activité n’est menée pour la riposte dans ces sous-bureaux de Cordaid. Dans les différents districts sanitaires, plusieurs lacunes ont été observées. Il s’agit de l’absence d’un plan de contingence, de l’insuffisance d’infrastructures répondant aux normes pouvant abriter les patients, l’absence/insuffisance de connaissances du personnel médical, du laboratoire et autres secteurs impliqués sur la maladie à coronavirus, une faible surveillance épidémiologique de la maladie à coronavirus, une faible capacité des laboratoires dans les prélèvements d’acheminement des d’échantillons pour la confirmation des cas à Bangui, l’insuffisance de mesures de préventions et de contrôle de l’infection et l’insuffisance de communication autour de la maladie à coronavirus. A l’hôpital d’Alindao où Cordaid appui avec le financement DFID, il n’y a aucun dispositif de prise en charge en cas d’enregistrement des cas positifs. Des pourparlers avec les différents bailleurs nous montrent qu’il n’y a pas assez de possibilités pour le financement des activités de prévention du COVID-19. Le fonds Bêkou-UE est en partie favorable pour une réallocation budgétaire mais la priorité est donnée aux activités prévues et qui doivent être exécutées. Seules les activités qui ne seront pas supportées par le projet Bêkou-UE vont être budgétisées dans la zone d’intervention du projet. Pour les projets financés par DFID (Alindao), Banque Mondiale, le Ministère des affaires étrangères du Pays-Bas et Fonds Mondial, il n’y a pas de possibilités de réallocation budgétaire pour la lutte contre le COVID-19. Face à cette pandémie, nous devrons mener rapidement des actions de prévention et de communication dans nos différentes zones d’action afin d’éviter le pire. Ce projet est complémentaire au projet Wash existants dans les sous bureaux de Cordaid et les districts concernés. Un projet semi-restricted Wash a été approuvé par le siège mais il ne concerne que peu de FOSA que compte les districts sanitaires concernés.

Les bénéficiaires directs du projet sont composées des populations des DS d’Alindao-Mingala, de Kembé-Satéma, Mobaye-Zangba, Bangassou, Ouango-Gambo, Berbérati, Bouar-Baoro et Sangha-Mbaéré. La population totale de ces 8 districts sanitaires est de 1 623 926 habitants.

l'objectif global est de contribuer à la lutte contre le Coronavirus en RCA l'objectif spécifique est de renforcer les mesures de prévention et la communication pour arrêter la propagation de la maladie à COVID-19.

Strengthening the resilience of communities in the Prefecture of Ouham-Pendé, Basse Kotto and Bouar-RCA to the pandemic of COVID 19

description.narrative:
The Central African Republic has been plagued by insecurity and conflict throughout its post-independence period. The CAR is home to 14 armed factions and many local militia groups, which currently control 80% of territory in the CAR. In term of population CAR has 4,595,000 peoples.
In term of health, the coverage in the Central African Republic remains and continues to remain a major challenge for the government and partners working in this field. For the World Health Organization (WHO), it is essential for everyone to be able to obtain the care they need, when they need it. Unfortunately, it is still difficult today for Central Africans to have access to quality health care.
The growing insecurity affecting the country only aggravates the situation. Health facilities are ransacked and vandalized by armed men. Several hospitals and health centres lack qualified staff and specialists. In addition, the technical facilities are below expectations.
The population is exposed to epidemics and other pathologies such as Covid 19.
In addition to the problem of infrastructure, there is also the problem of medical equipment and products, accessibility due to the poor state of the safety road.
With this global pandemic, it will be very difficult for the CAR to cope if the situation worsens as it is in other countries due to the way it is spreading rapidly.
At this stage, as the CAR has already recorded 5 positive cases, with the influx of expatriates, foreign traders and population movement visiting other countries; barrier measures, hand washing and awareness of the danger posed by this virus and means of protecting oneself and others would break the chain of contamination, thus avoiding the worst that would come to the country with this pandemic.
To prevent and break the chain of contamination of Covid 19 to the health of the Central African population at the level of bouar, alindao, bangassou and bocaranga.

Total beneficiaries: 70000 (just an estimation) Women: N/A Children: N/A Men: N/A Elderly: N/A
The selection of beneficiaries is estimated by considering the number of IDPs living in the Alindao site, the pupils of the targeted schools, and the local populations of Bocaranga, Bouar and Bangassou Disabled: N/A
