Response to Desert Locust Disaster in Ethiopia

description.narrative:
The Desert Locust Joint Response has targeted a total of 215.455 beneficiaries (without double counting). The DLJR is targeting the population in Locust affected IPC3 and IPC3+, in the most food insecure areas of Nugal, Awdal, Woqooyi Galbeed, Togdheer & Sool (Somalia) and Dire Dawa, Oromia & Somali (Ethiopia). Women and children are disproportionately affected, and special efforts will be made to reach the most vulnerable women and children including PLW and children under the age of 5. The division of targeted, direct beneficiaries per sector is as follows:
* Food Security & Livelihoods 66.080 * WASH 142.315 * Health 200 * Multi-purpose cash 37.762 * Accountability 1.862

The current locust crisis in the Horn of Africa is the worst outbreak of locusts in over 25 years in Ethiopia and Somalia and the worst observed in over 70 years in Kenya. The situation rapidly deteriorated in January 2020 as weather conditions have been unusually conducive to the spread of the pest. These conditions will allow breeding until June 2020 and could lead to 500 times more locusts, with the formation of large numbers of swarms. Desert locusts are expected to continue to breed and spread during the coming months. Given their life cycle, the March-April start of the long rains, coinciding with a regeneration of rangeland and the start of planting activities, will enable a new wave of breeding and further spread of the pest. Desert locusts have already reached northern Uganda, and looking forward, the infestation could: 1) spread further into the Rift Valley (especially in Ethiopia), as well as to South Sudan, 2) affect the 2020 main and secondary staple cropping seasons, and 3) continue to affect rangeland across the region. The desert locust is considered the most destructive migratory pest in the world as it is highly mobile and feeds on large quantities of any kind of green vegetation, including crops, pasture and fodder. A typical swarm can be made up of 150 million locusts per square kilometre and is carried on the wind, up to 150 km in one day. Even a very small, 1 km2 locust swarm (approx. 40 million desert locusts) can eat the same amount of food in one day as about 35 000 people. This can be especially devastating in areas where food security is poor and, where every gram of food produced counts towards minimizing gaps in a family’s food consumption. Currently, the region faces widespread food insecurity. In Ethiopia, an estimated 8.5 million people are severely food insecure, Phase 3 and above, according to IPC between February and June 2020. In Somalia, from February to September 2020, the population in IPC Phases 3 (Crisis) and 4 (Emergency) is expected to rise by 40 percent, from 1.1 million to 1.6 million people. Drivers of this food insecurity include climate shocks, conflict, and macroeconomic crises.
Ethiopia has been responding to the current swarm invasions since July 2019. To date, hopper bands have covered more than 429 km² of the country. Two generations of breeding have caused large numbers of swarms to form and move to Kenya and Somalia. In January 2020, the swarms were also seen moving towards the Rift Valley in Ethiopia and Kenya’s breadbasket. This would pose a serious threat, especially as Ethiopia already has an estimated 8.5 million people facing severe food insecurity. In Somalia, where 6.7 million people are now regarded as acutely food insecure (IPC Phase 2 and above), swarms bred in the north of the country and have moved mainly to central and southern regions. The pest is affecting pasture and threatening staple food crops in rural areas. Insecurity and a lack of national capacity have hampered control operations. The Somalia Food Security Cluster showed their findings in a presentation; the number of people affected was shown as over 2.5 million (21% of Somalia’s population) and especially pastoralist, agro-pastoralist, riverine and IDPs are affected

The key objective of the Acute Joint Response in locust-affected Ethiopia and Somalia is to provide life-saving assistance to people facing severe food insecurity. The design of the intervention is based on the sectors directly related to the locust infestation (FSL + MPC), in line with the cluster recommendations, based on the expertise of partners and complementarity with other ongoing interventions. The intervention will target the most vulnerable HHs, to improve direct access to food, protect and rebuild livelihoods, which contributes to the structural approach addressing the infestation. All responses are adapted to the current COVID-19 pandemic, and activities are carried out in a way to minimise risk to both staff and beneficiaries and reduce the spread. Most interventions incorporate activities to raise awareness on hygiene and disease prevention, and in some cases respond directly with additional Health and WASH interventions. Partners will work in rural as well as urban areas, depending on the locally identified needs. Across all areas, relevant cluster, SPHERE, and CHS standards are followed

title.narrative: Conditional and unrestricted cash
CSH-I2: Number of people benefitting from conditional and unrestricted cash transfers

description.narrative: A conditional transfer requires beneficiaries to undertake a specific action/activity (e.g. attending school, building a shelter, attending nutrition screenings, undertaking work, trainings, etc.) in order to receive assistance; i.e. a condition must be fulfilled before the transfer is received. Unrestricted transfers can be used entirely as the recipient chooses i.e. there are no restrictions on how the transfer is spent (Definitions of CALP). Conditional cash transfers can include cash for work, cash for assets and cash for training.

title.narrative: Hygiene promotion (Awareness)
WSH-I6: Number of people reached with hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities

description.narrative: Hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities. Could be training, campaigns, radio broadcasts, flyers etc. Excludes the distribution of Hygiene/dignity kits that should be covered under WHS-I1.

title.narrative: Hygiene promotion
WSH-I1: Number of people having regular access to soap to meet hygienic needs

description.narrative: Regular and timely access: 250g soap/p/m for personal hygiene, 200g soap/p/month for laundry. This includes hygiene/dignity kits. Access may be in-kind or though voucher distribution or through unconditional restricted cash to enable beneficiary to buy soap (without compromising access to other basic needs). Distributed items need to be culturally acceptable i.e. take into account local practice and expectations.

title.narrative: Short-term livelihood support
FSC-I1: Number of people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihoods assets

description.narrative: Resources that enable people to protect and rebuild their livelihood assets include seeds, livestock, tools, business grant, etc. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, restricted cash) and combination thereof to support, protect and enable the restoration/protection/access of/to livelihood assets.

title.narrative: Unconditional and unrestricted cash
CSH-I1: Number of people benefitting from unconditional and unrestricted cash transfers

description.narrative: Unconditional transfers are provided to beneficiaries without the recipient having to do anything in return in order to receive the assistance . Unrestricted transfers can be used entirely as the recipient chooses i.e. there are no restrictions on how the transfer is spent (Definitions of CALP). It can be delivered e.g. through local banks, shops, traders, local money transfer companies, remittance companies and post offices in either one or several instalments.

title.narrative: ACC-I1: Number of crisis-affected people who are also involved in the design, implementation, monitoring and/or evaluation of the programme

description.narrative: Participation is defined as the involvement of crisis-affected people in one or more phases of the programme: assessment, design, implementation, monitoring or evaluation. Participation does not take place when activities are carried out in exchange for a salary of 'in-kind' payment unless the affected people are involved in decision-making processes and have an impact on decisions that affect them. title.narrative: Accountability
ACC-I1: Number of crisis-affected people who are also involved in the design, implementation, monitoring and/or evaluation of the programme

description.narrative: Participation is defined as the involvement of crisis-affected people in one or more phases of the programme: assessment, design, implementation, monitoring or evaluation. Participation does not take place when activities are carried out in exchange for a salary of 'in-kind' payment unless the affected people are involved in decision-making processes and have an impact on decisions that affect them. Please describe in the actvity description what this involvement specifically entails and in which phase of the program conflict-affected people are involved.

Emergency COVID-19 response in Iraq

description.narrative: Host community, IDP

Long-term objectives, Flatten the curve, cure as many COVID- 19 patients as possible and prevent others from getting infected by information to communities. Short-term objectives; To provide life-saving primary health care for COVID- 19 patients and to protect health care staff.

The COVID_19/Coronavirus is continued to be detected in an increasing number of countries, and has become a major global pandemic, with multiple consequences on health, primarily related to the global economy. There is growing concern among the local health authorities about the possibility of domestic transmission of the disease which would challenge the already vulnerable health system in the country, stretched by years of wars and internal crises. The health authorities had already banned major public events, suspended schools, and closed malls and gathering places. Cordaid started their emergency work in Iraq in 2015 and continued with Primary Healthcare, physical rehabilitation and actions on MHPSS and GBV for PHCCs and hospitals in Anbar, Erbil, Ninawa and Salah Al-Din. Those PHCCs are normally well equipped, but because of the COVID- 19 outbreak more support is needed. That is why the Ministry of Health has asked Cordaid to provide lifesaving medication, consumables, medical equipment, medical waste management and awareness raising.

Humanitarian Aid - Health Nexus on COVID-19 response in Ethiopia

description.narrative:
Long term Objectives:
- To support the Regional Health Bureaus in ensuring adequate preparedness capacity to prevent COVID-19 in targeted areas. - To improve the response preparedness and capacity of health facilities and COVID-19 isolation centers through provision of basic equipment and consumables required for management of (suspected) COVID-19 cases
Short Term Objectives:
- To increase community knowledge and awareness regarding COVID-19 through the distribution of COVID-19 Information-Education-Communication (IECs) materials in communities where Cordaid operates - To contribute to prevention of COVID-19 through distribution of hand washing soaps, sanitizers and surface disinfectants to community members and health facilities where Cordaid operates - Strengthen the preparedness capacity of the community and health facilities in Cordaid program operational areas to prevent the risk of Corona virus and quickly respond when occurred.

Men and Women in Oromia and Somali Regional State:
- Direct: 2,000,000 - Indirect: 10,000,000 Men: 980,000 - Women: 1,020,000
105 Health Facilities

The COVID-19 pandemic is accelerating. It took 67 days from reported case to reach the first 100K cases, 11 days to reach 200K cases but only just 4 days to surpass the 300k mark. These numbers matter! These are people, whose lives and families are seriously affected.1 The number of confirmed cases worldwide has exceeded 300,000 and many epidemiologists believe the real total of infections may be close to a million because testing and reporting are so incomplete.
Currently, 189 countries are affected with cases of COVID-19, with 334,984 confirmed cases in the world and 14,652 deaths. Ethiopia has confirmed a total of 16 cases of COVID-19, since the confirmation of the first case on March 13th, 2020. The number of people who have had contact with confirmed cases is 319.
The WHO has warned that COVID-19 could spread to countries with weaker health systems including sub-Saharan Africa – where poor sanitation facilities, the proliferation of the informal economy and urban crowding pose additional challenges in the efforts to combat the highly infectious disease. 062 million people in Ethiopia lack access to safe water and 97 million lack access to improved sanitation. According to a study conducted in 11 cities in Ethiopia, the number of citizens who live on the streets has reached around 88 thousand. The report also indicates that many of the homeless are found at provisional capitals. Out of the 88 thousand homeless population, children, women, youth and the elderly account for the majority. Addis Ababa, home to one of Africa’s busiest international airline hubs, Ethiopia is bolstering preparedness to contain a potential outbreak of COVID-19. Health authorities are tightening up surveillance, diagnosis, epidemic response coordination and public health education to swiftly detect cases and limit widespread infections. Ethiopia is among 13 African countries the World Health Organization (WHO) considers as top priority for COVID-19 preparedness due to direct links or a high volume of travel to countries which are highly affected by Corona virus.
The Government of Ethiopia announced availing 5 billion birr (about $154 million) to combat the spread of COVID-19 pandemic and to undertake preparedness tasks. Moreover, $52,000 Test kits , molecular detector for COVID-19 detection, 102,000 masks and 2 million RMB anti-epidemic supplies are donated to the Ethiopian ministry of public health institute.
Around 60 rapid response team members, including from other regions of the country, have been trained on coronavirus preparedness. WHO has deployed technical experts in surveillance, point-of-entry management, infection prevention and control, public health communication and logistics to assist the Ethiopian government’s readiness to respond to COVID-19. WHO has also provided equipment and supplies, including reagents to test for corona virus.
One isolation and two treatment centres with a total bed capacity of 109 have been established. The health workers at Bole Chefe rigorously follow the protocol for proper protection when handling patients suspected to have coronavirus. If a patient is confirmed to have the virus, they are transferred to the treatment centre for confirmed cases at Eko Kotebe Hospital. One treatment centre is designated for suspected cases and additional one for severe and critical cases. These centres are equipped with respirator machines.

Philippines Prevention COVID-19

description.narrative: Objective: Reduce the spread of COVID-19 for frontline health workers and marginalized vulnerable groups; the urban poor, informal settlers, and IDPs in 6 regions in the Philippines.

The Philippine government declared on March 16, 2020, a State of Calamity throughout the Philippines for a tentative period of six months. The Metro Manila and the entire Luzon island was put under "enhanced community quarantine” which is effectively a total lockdown, restricting the movement of the population. Additional lockdown restrictions mandated the temporary closure of non-essential shops and businesses. This has been cascaded with varying level of severity to most municipalities, cities and provinces throughout the Philippines during the last 2 weeks of March. Current transmission classification in the Philippines is identified as clusters of cases with evidence of community transmission in highly urbanised areas of National Capitol Region (Metro Manila), Cebu and Davao. Vulnerabilities include: - All Local Government Units and Health providers are reporting dire lack of PPEs, testing kits and facilities to manage the daily increase in numbers of people reporting with symptoms, - There is very limited handwashing and hygiene facilities associated any location where people are contained and tested are extremely limited through the islands and regions, markets remain open as do ports to enable movement of food and essential goods between islands however there is very limited control on social distancing in these facilities and poor management of hygiene to minimize exposure. In remote and island regions of the Philippines limited water access is a norm which many communities are accustomed to, however these limits safe hygiene practices needed to control the spread of the virus. - For the poor in the Philippines, some 25,000,000 people living in basic or informal settlements surrounding the countries cities and towns the impossible challenge of lock down, unable to stop work to provide a daily wage for food and essentials, for many families living conditions already cramped with no access to hygiene or sanitation facilities, being able to safety maintain social distancing and hygiene is a significant challenge in halting the spread of the virus. The national government confirmed the Social Amelioration Program (SAP) P200 billion budget allocation for emergency subsidies to 18 million low-income households; P5,000 to P8,000 each month (between 90 and 145 Euros) for two months. Slow and bureaucratic systems of local government will impact access for the poor, this is not sufficient to provide for a family. - In southern Mindanao, a region known for protracted conflict there are approximately 350,000 people displaced by conflict between Philippines Armed Forces and armed non-state actors or but typhoons and earthquakes. The project responds to the importance of front-liners and vulnerable communities enhancing their capacity to protect themselves in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The PfR project in the Philippines enabled the building of the following alliances and platforms 1. Calamianes Resilience Network (Northern Palawan) 2. Guiuan Cooperation Platform (Eastern Samar) 3. Mandaue Resilience Network Metro Cebu) 4. Bulacan Resilience Network (Metro Manila) We also work with two key national partners, 5. ICSC (the Institute for Climate and Sustainable Cities in Metro Manila) 6. Ecoweb in Mindanao: These networks have ability to reach the selected most vulnerable/ marginalised groups, Therefore we deliberately decided for a strategy to support and facilitate all 5 networks to reach these groups that have difficulties (barriers) in accessing information and assistance. By supporting those networks the reach will be extensive. All 5 networks have significant support through not only the PfR but also through Local Government Units, Local CSO and People’s organizations, Universities. Each network has a Cordaid staff attached to the network for coordination and operations, at national level strategic strategies and cooperation are streamed through the national Cordaid Philippines office and National Partners a

One Cordaid DRC against COVID-19

description.narrative:
Overall objective: to help curb the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic in DRC. Specific objectives:
- Strengthening risk communication and the participation and commitment of local communities through RECO and local radios, in order to ensure that they take ownership of community activities to prevent and respond to a possible coronavirus epidemic and that these activities are taken into account across all the pillars of the response. - Supporting victims from domestic and sexual violence. - Strengthening the coordination of community activities in each targeted health zones.

Since the outbreak of Coronavirus (COVID-19) in Wuhan, China, the global public health threat posed by COVID-19 is high, with more than 1,400,000 reported cases worldwide. The DRC Ministry of Health confirmed the first case of COVID-19 in the DRC on March 10, 2020. The DRC President decided enhanced screening, quarantine measures and movement restrictions to reduce the spread of COVID-19, along with recommended basic protective measures (hand-washing and social distancing). However, DRC is a vast country, with more than 80 million inhabitants leaving in dire conditions. The health system is weak and will not be able to handle a major health crisis. Many people don’t have access to clean water, stay together in small spaces and live from hand-to-mouth. In addition, a health crisis could rapidly turn into a social crisis, as the informal sector accounts for more than 80% of the economy. Faced with the spread of this epidemic in DRC, it is urgent to sensitize populations to raise awareness of the danger posed by this disease and to respect the recommendations of the health authorities for proper prevention against the pandemic.
As a result, prevention and preparedness are key to prevent from a global crisis in DRC.
Target groups – RECO, health care providers, community leaders, local civil society organizations (especially youth organizations), local authorities

title.narrative: Access to Life saving basic services provided
Number of people enabled to meet their basic food needs in response to COVID-19
Solving shortages of essential health commodities and acute problems in the supply chain during the COVID-19 pandemic in three fragile countries.

description.narrative: The Covid-19 epidemic is having a large impact on the most fragile countries in the world where health systems are weak and ill-prepared for prevention and mitigation activities. Supply chains of essential health commodities to health facilities have also been disrupted aggravating the impact on the sector. Low income countries lack the funds to implement their Covid-19 Readiness and Response plans. There is a lack of PPE (personal protection equipment) for health staff and for community health workers and in shortage of supplies and medicines is bound to have a negative impact on the provision and use of primary health care services and on sexual and reproductive health (SRH) services. In the countries where Cordaid has its largest health programmes (DRC, CAR and Burundi), we can expect poor public health outcomes and results. To mitigate these effects Cordaid management approved 1.192.621 for these three countries for procuring PPE, medicines and medical supplies with the technical support of I+solutions, a supply-chain specialist with whom Cordaid has worked successfully in a.o. DRC.

The primary objective was to provide an initial boost to country-owned initiatives to respond accurately and timely to possibly upcoming Covid-19 epidemic community-transmitted outbreaks in three fragile countries where Cordaid has sizable health programs, i.e. Burundi, Central African Republic and Democratic Republic of Congo. A secondary objective referred to creating goodwill for Cordaid with government and donors so that Cordaid would be considered as a trustworthy and action-oriented International NGO, willing and able to contribute to the in-country Covid-19 plans for preparedness and responses. The appreciation would also include Cordaid’s ability to provide procurement services in partnership with I+ Solutions. Another secondary objective was to explore partnership with i+solutions on procurement, rather than just strengthening the supply-chain in-country which was the experience of cooperation between the two organizations until then. This with a view to an eventual framework agreement between the two organizations.

The ultimate beneficiaries are the populations of health catchment areas served by Cordaid health projects in Burundi, Central African Republic and Democratic Republic of Congo, the health staff of these facilities and Cordaid programme staff.

title.narrative: Educating girls

description.narrative:
Malgré d’importants progrès enregistrés en République démocratique du Congo dans le secteur de l'éducation en termes d’amélioration du taux d’achèvement au niveau primaire, qui est passé de 29 % en 2002 à 70 % en 2014, on estimait en 2017 que 3,5 millions soit 26,7 % des enfants en âge de fréquenter le primaire n’étaient pas scolarisés. Parmi eux, 2,75 millions vivent dans des zones rurales. D’après diverses études (DFID, UNICEF, Banque mondiale), le profil type des enfants déscolarisés est le suivant : filles issues des ménages les plus pauvres, dont le chef de ménage n’a aucun niveau d’instruction et résidant en milieu rural.
Les déterminants de l’exclusion scolaire sont principalement d’ordres socio-culturels et économiques. Les raisons économiques sont très présentes : outre le manque de moyens pour payer les fournitures scolaires et les uniformes, certaines familles très pauvres ont recours à leurs enfants pour les aider dans leur activité professionnelle ou pour les tâches ménagères, ou bien font directement travailler leurs enfants, qui représentent des sources de revenus indispensables à la survie de l’ensemble de la famille. De fait, les obstacles financiers sont la principale entrave à la fréquentation scolaire, forçant les familles pauvres à renoncer à l’éducation de leurs enfants, et en particulier des filles. En outre, les enfants vivant dans des régions mal desservies et difficiles d’accès sont exclus de façon disproportionnée du système éducatif du fait des problèmes d’accès aux établissements (distance importante domicile – établissement) et de la mauvaise qualité de l'environnement d'apprentissage (salles de classe en mauvais état, manque de sanitaires, d’eau, d’électricité, etc.). Les obstacles socio-culturels sont également nombreux, en particulier en milieu rural (mariages précoces, poids de la tradition patriarcale, prévalence de l’apprentissage des filles à devenir des épouses et des mère). Les résultats de diverses enquêtes révèlent des inégalités de genre dans l’éducation. Il en ressort que si les efforts déployés par l’État et ses partenaires dans la scolarisation des enfants ces dernières années ont permis de réduire les inégalités d’accès à l’école entre garçons et filles, des inégalités de genre existent toujours, surtout en milieu rural en défaveur des filles. Les logiques matrimoniales familiales et les grossesses précoces expliquent en partie cette déperdition scolaire plus importante chez les filles.
La République démocratique du Congo a mis en place la Stratégie Sectorielle de l'Education et Formation (SSEF) pour la période 2016-2025 en mettant l'accent sur l'élargissement de l'accès et de l'équité, l'amélioration de la qualité de l'apprentissage et l'amélioration de la gouvernance et de la gestion dans le secteur. Pour l’éducation au niveau primaire, trois objectifs stratégiques sont visés, notamment, 1) promouvoir un système d'éducation équitable pour la croissance en permettant à tous les enfants de bénéficier d'une éducation primaire gratuite, combinée à des mesures spécifiques pour les populations défavorisées et les enfants ayant des besoins spéciaux ; 2) créer un environnement qui renforce un système éducatif de qualité en développant des mécanismes de suivi et d'assurance qualité et développer un environnement éducatif propice à un apprentissage de qualité, grâce à la fourniture de matériel et d'équipement d'apprentissage pour les élèves et des formations pour les enseignants 3) améliorer la transparence et l'efficacité de la gouvernance et de la gestion du secteur.
À partir de l’année scolaire 2019-2020, le gouvernement a déclaré la gratuité pour l’éducation primaire dans tout le pays. Cette politique de gratuité de l’école souffre néanmoins de nombreuses défaillances et contribue au surpeuplement de salles de classe dont les capacités d’accueil sont insuffisantes au regard des normes de nombre d’élèves par classe (moyenne de 50 par classe). La situation est d’autant plus accentuée dans le Kasaï central à cause de la crise sociale de 2017 qui a contribué à la dégradation des infrastructures scolaires. Cette situation a des effets délétères sur les capacités d’’absorption de tous les enfants non scolarisés mais contribue également l’abandon de certains enfants scolarisés.
Selon un rapport de 2018 de l’Institut national de la statistique, le taux net de scolarisation au Kasaï Central est de 81,1 au primaire et 45,4% au secondaire (moyenne nationale : 78,1% au primaire et 48,1% au secondaire). Mais ces données datent de 2016, juste avant la crise du Kasaï qui a déstructuré le tissu socio-économique de cette région. Il est sûr que la crise a provoqué une diminution de la scolarisation des enfants dans la province pour raison de déplacements et des destructions d’écoles.
A cette situation fragile vient s’ajouter le contexte de pandémie de COVID-19 ayant entrainé la fermeture des établissements scolaires de la RDC depuis le 19 mars 2020. Dans un pays où l’accès à l’électricité, à internet, aux livres et aux manuels scolaires est réduit, cette fermeture aggrave la vulnérabilité des enfants marginalisés.

Objectif. 1 : Contribuer à la continuité des études des enfants à la maison durant la période de restrictions dues au COVID-19, jusqu’à la réouverture des écoles Objectif 2 : Contribuer à la scolarisation des 1 125 (filles et garçons) dans 25 écoles de la province de Kasaï Central, Objectif 3 : Contribuer à la réhabilitation des lieux de vie (salles de classes et latrines) Objectif 4 : Valoriser cette expérience par la réalisation d’une vidéo et de photos.

title.narrative: The Humanitarian Response was Timely

description.narrative:
SPHERE: Communities and people affected by crisis, including the most vulnerable groups, consider that the timing of the assistance and protection they receive is adequate. DRA: timely depends on the nature of the acute crisis (slow versus sudden onset). If it is an acute sudden onset crisis a response is considered timely if we decide to respond within 48 hours and if we initiate the response within 72 hours. If it is a slow onset crisis, it is timely if we initiate the response in 3 weeks after we decide that the crisis meets the criteria of an acute crisis.
The applicable definition depends on the type of crisis (protracted versus acute). The SPHERE definition should be used in more protracted crisis where there is (more) time to conduct assessments and measure satisfaction of the response in the eyes of people affected. The DRA definition should be used for acute crises, where it is more important to initiate the response as soon as possible and look at our own processes.

title.narrative: Access to Life saving basic services provided
Number of people enabled to meet their basic food needs in response to COVID-19
COVID-19 Response for vulnerable people in Taiz

description.narrative:
The COVID-19 pandemic is devastating lives, public health systems, livelihoods and economies across the world including Yemen. The COVID-19 crisis is further exacerbating the humanitarian crisis in Yemen, as the country is experiencing the largest humanitarian crisis in the world today. Yemen’s health infrastructure and systems have been weakened by five years of conflict. 50% of health facilities are functioning, and only 4 CPHL are operational which are Sanaa, Aden, Mukalla and Taiz. In addition, there are no incentives for health workers due to shortage in fund in MoPHP this year which makes it harder to retain the health workers to respond to COVID-19 in health facilities. There is limited medicine, equipment and personal protection equipment (PPE) available. There are only 500 ventilators in the country, and just four labs able to do coronavirus testing, according to Save the Children. WHO estimates that 55 per cent of people in Yemen will be infected with COVID-19, 42,000 will die and over 292,000 will require hospitalization. The WHO has said it fears the worst about the COVID-19 impact on Yemen, as its population has some of the lowest levels of immunity and most acute vulnerability to disease compared with other countries. Furthermore, there is a very little information on COVID-19 available, even among health staff and overall measures are not taken so seriously or, are not a priority after 5 years of war. Yemen has currently 184 confirmed cases and 30 deaths (ACAPS 20 May), with Sana’a and Aden mostly affected. According to the news, currently 80 people a day are dying in Aden, many of them have COVID-19 symptoms but with limited testing capacity available, cases go unconfirmed.
Taiz: is Yemen’s longest-running battlefield, the most heavily bombed by blistering Saudi airstrikes, the deadliest governorate in Yemen’s devastating war. Currently the city is divided into 2 parts and has also a curfew and has closed all entry point to the governorate, except for the entry points of goods and supplies for the health sector. The imposed curfew is a severe threat for people’s livelihoods. As in many areas in Yemen, people would like to take the virus seriously but need to choose between dying of Corona or dying of hunger. Taiz has currently 4 confirmed cases with one death.

The key target beneficiaries are vulnerable groups (IDPs, prisoners, marginalized groups). These three groups are the criteria that will be used for selecting the beneficiaries. Such groups are not integrated in the community; they live in either in slums (marginalized people) or in camps and building like schools (IDPs), while the prisoners are in the prisons. So, only these groups in such areas will be targeted even in the activity of cleaning sterilization campaign of the security and public health institutions; most of the beneficiaries of these institutions are vulnerable people, while other groups usually seek health services from private hospitals instead of the public ones.
To contribute to the containment of the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic and decrease morbidity and mortality

description.narrative: The World Bank Supported Additional Financing V Project Development Objective is to: A. Increase coverage and quality of an integrated package of Reproductive, Maternal, Neonatal, Child, Adolescent health and nutrition (RMNCAH-N) services, as well as B. Zimbabwe, a landlocked and lower-middle income country with a gross national income per capita of US$1,790 (Atlas method, 2018) and a population of 14.4 million (World Development Indicators/WDI 2019), was already facing a deep economic and humanitarian crisis prior to the COVID-19 pandemic. At the same time Zimbabwe had made commendable improvements in key health outcomes in the past decade, but progress was not fast enough to meet the country’s 2015 Millennium Development Goals and current projections fall short of its Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

title.narrative: Reducing transmission of COVID-19 & addressing immediate food security needs

description.narrative: Myanmar’s health system is weakened by 60 years of isolation and under investment, lack of schooling and training. The health system is lacking international exposure and networks as well. The corona virus pandemic is putting enormous pressure on the health system. Despite the difficult past and current bottlenecks, Myanmar’s health workers are giving everything they have to fight the current Covid-19 pandemic.

Targeted groups are migrants who moved back to Burma due to the virus and majority are jobless, additionally factory workers are targets as well since most factories shut down due to government restriction and lack of materials received from China.

The project's overall objective is to reduce the impact of the Covid-19. The purpose of the case is so that vulnerable people are better protected against the virus as well are the loss to livelihoods in the target area To reduce spreading of the Covid-19 virus through distribution of protective materials (33,421 people) in combination with awareness raising. Distribution of food and/or cash to (7,275 people) vulnerable and left-behind groups which are cut off of their livelihoods.

Strengthening COVID-19 Response in Afghanistan

description.narrative: 8.4 million direct and indirect beneficiaries, made up of 4.3 million male and 4.1 million female beneficiaries, including children. This will include: • Establishment of 30 COVID-19 sample collection points • Increase oxygen capacity in nine provincial hospitals by establishing oxygen plants • Reach 96,378 patients with food baskets and nutrition counselling services • Train 31,689 (15,291 women) community members on recognizing COVID-19 symptoms and prevention measures • 55% of population in targeted programme areas to be reached with COVID-19 prevention messages • 320 (160 women) provincial and district hospital staff to receive IPC training • 22 district and community health centre staff trained in Badakhshan on COVID-19 case management through eHealth

The coronavirus disease (COVID-19) was declared a pandemic on 11 March 2020 by the World Health Organization (WHO). According to John Hopkins University data, as of 1 October 2020, there have been 33, 997, 825 confirmed cases and 1,014,588 deaths worldwide. As the pandemic develops, countries with weaker health systems, limited capacity to deal with major outbreaks, and large populations of already vulnerable communities are at particular risk; this includes Afghanistan.
In Afghanistan, as of 29 September 2020, the Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) reported that 39,285 people across all 34 provinces have tested positive for COVID-19. Kabul is the epicentre of the outbreak; Herat, Kandahar, and Balkh provinces closely follow (1,458 individuals are confirmed to have died from the virus ). The relatively low level of infection, especially juxtaposed with the high number of Afghans who have returned from Iran and Pakistan in recent months, can be attributed to low community-testing and slow processing of test results – especially for those in rural, remote and insecure areas. Tellingly, while the number of reported positive cases has dropped, the rate of death has risen. There are currently 11 testing laboratories in the country; the government hopes to eventually have 15 operational. The graph below presents the breakdown of COVID-19 confirmed cases in Afghanistan

participating-org.narrative: EU Directorate-General for International Cooperation and Development

organisation.narrative: EU Directorate-General for International Cooperation and Development

title.narrative: COVID-19 & (S)GBV

description.narrative:
1) To build better coordination and linkages between targeted communities and local authorities in dealing with (S)GBV.
2) To raise awareness among the ministry of Interior & Health to sensitive police, Afghan citizens & elders of the community, shura and religious leaders and on the action needed to identify and mitigate (S)GBV during COVID-19 and beyond.

Direct beneficiary : 15,000 , 3000 per province Indirect :15000*5= 75000
The project targets only women in five provinces

In a patriarchal society like Afghanistan, women and girls face many challenges and during the COVID 19 crises, the main concern is often not the virus itself but survival. Due to lock down measures, people are conﬁned, poverty and unemployment are increasing. Also, protection and health systems are weak and women and girls are at greater risk of experiencing gender-based violence. Despite the lack of data in Afghanistan, emerging evidence shows that, with the COVID-19 crisis, the number of women and girls experiencing (domestic) violence, has increased in all provinces of Afghanistan. A “gender alert” on COVID19 -Afghanistan, conducted by UN women during May 2020, indicates that violence against women and girls (VAWG), particularly domestic violence, has increased during COVID-19. Recent evidence indicates that, all over Afghanistan, violence against women increased significantly. In a survey done by OXFAM, 97% of female respondents said that gender-based violence has already increased since the COVID 19 outbreak started. Afghanistan already sees high levels of domestic violence – 87% of Afghan women reportedly experience at least one form of physical, sexual or psychological violence, during COVID-19.
Lockdowns and quarantine measures mean that many women are conﬁned with their abusers, with limited options for seeking help and support in a context with increased tensions. This is particularly true in Afghanistan, where women have already limited access to essential services. Life-saving care and support to (S)GBV survivors may be disrupted when front-line service providers and systems, such as health, policing and social welfare, are overburdened and focused on handling COVID-19 cases.
Afghanistan is one of the most fragile countries in the world. It is already burdened far beyond its capacity to address major social (health and education) and economic challenges due to insecurity, war and conflict. Afghanistan, a country suffering from armed conflict, is also dealing with structural inequalities, injustice and poverty. The Afghan government, especially the Ministry of Health and health care service providers are therefore extra challenged facing COVID 19. Since the start of COVID 19 crises the confirmed cases reached 27,537 people across all 34 provinces. 546 people have died and 7,660 recovered. (OCHA, 2020) (OCHA, 2020, (S)GBV cases have also been registered during the service delivery by OCHA. Women and girls face countless problems due to patriarchal norms limiting their movements, access to basic to their basic rights, as freedom of movement, making and sharing their decisions and views at household and community level. Rape, honor killing, forced marriage has registered a big challenge in the war and insecure context of Afghanistan. Talking about sexual violence is a social taboo and survivors of sexual violence often suffer alone and they don’t know that (S)GBV is a common threat in Afghan society due to the lack of debate in society.
Other worrisome responses provided from health workers were related to lack of knowledge of the prevalence of SGBV in Afghanistan, consequences of SGBV specifically related to HIV/AIDS, and risk factors related to women experiencing and reporting violence. Only 52% of surveyed health workers accurately identified that Afghanistan has specific laws on GBV/IPV .
Focusing on prevention of and response to sexual violence in emergencies could help in addressing (S)GBV by ensuring broader interventions to cope with COVID 19 crisis in Afghanistan. GBV & (S)GBV are cross cutting issues and interventions on these issues need to be mainstreamed across any development and services delivery interventions. By addressing GBV & (S)GBV we can help to enhance the protective factors to prevent the cases using coordinated approach. This project will not directly intervene, but ensure people who have experience (S)GBV, will be receiving the relevant information where to go to for support. And COVID 19 intervention teams will use coordinated approach by not only focusing on WASH interventions, but also informing about the risk of the increase of (S)GBV. By raising awareness with relevant stakeholders, we aim for them to become more sensitive to the subject and take it into account in their interventions.

Saving lives and protecting the livelihood of people affected by COVID-19 related restrictions, desert locust and flood in Liben cluster

description.narrative: 23,000 households (138,000 people) Male: 75,900 Female: 62,100

The Overall Objective of the action is to saving lives and increased the coping capacity of vulnerable and at-risk populations affected by desert locust, COVID-19 related restrictions, and flooding in the RESET zone of influence. The Specific Objective of the action is to meet basic needs and protect livelihoods of vulnerable and at-risk households in Mubarak Woreda of Liben cluster under RESET II program through an integrated and gender-sensitive, multi-sectoral response. The Specific Objective will be achieved through two Results: R1) Improved access to WASH services. R2) Emergency and recovery livelihood needs of targeted households are met through the provision of appropriate livestock and crop inputs and cash support. Below is the outline of activities to achieve the objectives

The humanitarian situation in the Liben cluster under the RESET II program worsening due to the combining effects of multiple crises. COVID-19-related restrictions, coupled with the broader economic decline, the spread of desert locust infestation, flooding, and the general decrease in income has led to atypically high humanitarian needs across the Liben cluster. An increase in food commodities and essential non-food commodities prices have been continuing due to poor terms of trade in the flood-affected woredas. This has resulted in many poor households having difficulty accessing market foods and Crisis (IPC Phase 3) outcomes are present. Thus, this Crisis Modifier action target lifesaving and livelihood protection activities including access to supplementary livestock feed, veterinary services, farm inputs, multipurpose cash transfer (cash-for-work, and unconditional), and response to the ongoing COVID-19 related WASH service.

title.narrative: Conditional and unrestricted cash

description.narrative: A conditional transfer requires beneficiaries to undertake a specific action/activity (e.g. attending school, building a shelter, attending nutrition screenings, undertaking work, trainings, etc.) in order to receive assistance; i.e. a condition must be fulfilled before the transfer is received. Unrestricted transfers can be used entirely as the recipient chooses i.e. there are no restrictions on how the transfer is spent (Definitions of CALP). Conditional cash transfers can include cash for work, cash for assets and cash for training.

Addressing basic needs of people affected by floods and violence in Jonglei

description.narrative: South Sudan has been facing unprecedented multi-dimensional nature of crises for many years. In 2020, South Sudan has been severely affected by conflict (national, intra/inter communal in nature), food insecurity (famine and economic depletion), Public health crises (Cholera outbreak and emergency of covid-19 pandemic), bad governance (political crises with the governorates of the states) and natural disasters (flash floods) This has been compounded with desert locust swarms and recent spike in commodity prices mid-2020. According to the World bank and National bureau of statistics the poverty levels of south Sudanese have increased from 51% to 82% between 2017 to 2019, and as of 2020, these figures may continue to increase. South Sudan is also ranked the most vulnerable country to Covid-19 in Africa and Food security is a major concern in the country Heavy rainfall over July-August resulted in overflow of the White Nile and its tributaries, affecting some 800,000 people across 37 counties in South Sudan with 368,000 people displaced to higher grounds in escape of the rising waters. Women and Children are the most affected. The number is likely to increase as further heavy rainfall is expected in the coming weeks. Jonglei, Upper Nile, Eastern Equatoria, and Warrap are the worst affected states. 980,000 people affected by flooding in 2019 also remain in need of aid. Restrictions related to COVID-19, together with increased insecurity in states like Jonglei, have been impeding affected populations' access to resources and relief. The Government of South Sudan has declared a state of emergency in Jonglei State and Pibor Administrative Area.
To provide life-saving assistance to 54,000 people affected by floods in Jonglei – Pigi/Canal County with WASH, FSL and S/NFI intervention.

Total beneficiaries: 54,000 individuals in total Women: 16,740 Children: 24,840 Men: 11,880 Elderly: 378 Disabled: 162
Explain how direct beneficiaries are selected or targeted: In consultation and coordination with UNOCHA, RRC, and all the clusters, Cordaid will target the most vulnerable households. For beneficiary targeting the cluster standards will be used. Criteria for beneficiary selection include: • Children • Women headed households • Child headed households • Elderly headed households and persons with specific needs (PSN) such as chronically ill, disabled people, PLW • Type of shelter and condition the beneficiaries are being accommodate in now. • Households with no basic items /or those who have lost most of their properties during the flooding.

title.narrative: ACM Lebanon Joint Response 2020

description.narrative: The explosion in Beirut on 4 August has caused wide-spread damage, and loss of lives with Beirut hospitals, already overwhelmed by COVID-19, unable to cope with the many wounded. In the hardest hit areas the blast destroyed houses, apartment blocks and livelihood. Doors, windows and roofs were blown away and buildings damaged. People fled these areas, and streets are deserted. The area is also the centre of (illegal) labour for Beirut’s many immigrants and refugees, who lost their jobs, scarce belongings and have no longer a roof above their heads. People are in urgent need of cash and shelter. In response, Cordaid through Caritas Switzerland and Caritas Lebanon (CL) will provide cash for shelter and MPC to the most vulnerable people in Rmeil and Burj Hammoud, incl migrants and refugees. Thus reducing protection (GBV and use of negative coping mechanisms) public health risks, especially for vulnerable women, girls, elderly and ill. The Government of Lebanon has approved the provision of CVA in Lebanon and multi-purpose cash assistance is the most prominent modality to cover basic needs in the ongoing refugee response. Cordaid, in accordance with its Cash and cash for shelter guidelines, will ensure that any risk associated with cash is mitigated making use of GBV and cash checklists.
The most vulnerable people in Rmeil and Burj Hammoud, incl migrants and refugees.

To assist the most vulnerable families, both Lebanese and migrants and refugees, to recover from the impact of the blast. This will be done through cash for shelter repairs and MPC in the affected areas Burj Hammoud and Rmeil.

description.narrative: Basic, safe and dignified: - affected individuals have an minimum covered floor area of 3.5m2 per person. - all shelter solutions and materials meet locally agreed technical and performance standards and are culturally acceptable. - all household (re-)construction is in accordance with safe building practices and standards. - all household (re-)construction demonstrate involvement of the affected population and/or are culturally acceptable by the affected population.

title.narrative: Unconditional and unrestricted cash

description.narrative: Unconditional transfers are provided to beneficiaries without the recipient having to do anything in return in order to receive the assistance . Unrestricted transfers can be used entirely as the recipient chooses i.e. there are no restrictions on how the transfer is spent (Definitions of CALP). It can be delivered e.g. through local banks, shops, traders, local money transfer companies, remittance companies and post offices in either one or several instalments.

title.narrative: Climate Resilience
The project integrates climate risks in programming

description.narrative:
Green: Project is successfully integrating climate risks in programming in accordance with project plan Orange: Project is integrate climate risks in programming; however, not fully in accordance with project plan OR integration of climate risks is not at a satisfactory level. Red: Project is NOT integrating climate risks in programming either because this was not planned for or it was planned, not done.
The integration of climate risks in programming included an undertaking of concrete actions to reduce and/or mitigate risks related to climate change impact and disaster risks ( for example droughts, erosion, salinization, flooding, etc) The projects we refer to could be on the themes of health education, justice, security, disaster management, finance and livelihoods.

title.narrative: The Humanitarian Response was Timely

description.narrative:
SPHERE: Communities and people affected by crisis, including the most vulnerable groups, consider that the timing of the assistance and protection they receive is adequate. DRA: timely depends on the nature of the acute crisis (slow versus sudden onset). If it is an acute sudden onset crisis a response is considered timely if we decide to respond within 48 hours and if we initiate the response within 72 hours. If it is a slow onset crisis, it is timely if we initiate the response in 3 weeks after we decide that the crisis meets the criteria of an acute crisis.
The applicable definition depends on the type of crisis (protracted versus acute). The SPHERE definition should be used in more protracted crisis where there is (more) time to conduct assessments and measure satisfaction of the response in the eyes of people affected. The DRA definition should be used for acute crises, where it is more important to initiate the response as soon as possible and look at our own processes.

title.narrative: Accountability
% of feedback and valid complaints received that are responded to/resolved

description.narrative: Percent of feedback and valid complaints received at project or country/field office level, via Cordaid, a partner or consortium member that are respond to and/or resolved (in accordance with Cordaid FCM minimum standards). This excludes invalid and sensitive complaints.

title.narrative: Localisation
LOC-I1: % of budget that went to national and local actors
Support to COVID-19 Affected Regions of Ethiopia (ECJR)

description.narrative: 125,000 individuals

Ethiopia is facing an unprecedented crisis due to the C-19 (C19) pandemic, compounded by a devastating desert locust invasion, widespread flooding, and rising food prices. While the government has ramped up its COVID-19 mitigation measures, there are remaining challenges with the weak health care system and persistent food insecurity. Outside of Addis Ababa, Somali and Amhara regions are 2 regions with the highest number of people in need among the regions with high confirmed cases due to weak health service systems, limited WASH facilities and high levels of food insecurity. The Amhara region has reported 1194 cases with Artuma Fursi woreda having a high level of COVID-19 vulnerability as it borders the Afar region, which serves as the main migration route from Djibouti and Arab countries. The woreda has no hospital and 6 health centres. The Somali region has 973 confirmed cases with the Shabelle zone capital of Gode, at high risk to COVID-19.It is also both a major road and air transport hub in the region. Gode has only one hospital and 4 health centres with Gode city hospital and Gode secondary school designated as quarantine centres. The weak health service system in the 2 woredas plus the limited equipment/supplies and damaged latrines/water structures in the quarantine centres badly need support. Therefore, this project aims at providing lifesaving activities in response to COVID-19 through four sectors of responses, Food security and livelihood, Multi-purpose cash, Health (including mental health), and WASH.

 To provide unconditional multi-purpose Cash(MPC) assistance to meet the basic needs of acute food insecure people,
 To provide accessible essential health services and COVID-19 Prevention and Control to targeted populations, focusing on main causes of morbidity and sexual and reproductive health.  To provide safe drinking water by providing water treatment chemicals, rehabilitation of non-functioning water points, and extension of pipe network from the existing scheme or construction of new water schemes.

title.narrative: Water Supply
WSH-I4: Number of people having access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use

description.narrative: Access: maximum distance to water point 500m, queuing time less than 15min, filling time maximum 3 min/20 litres or as locally agreed. Water access should be during the whole period of implementation unless action is mostly related to building the local water delivery capacity. Sufficient: covering basic needs, i.e. 7.5-15 l/p/d or as locally agreed. Safe: 1) low risk of faecal contamination, 2) No faecal coliforms detectable in any 100-ml sample, 3) For piped water supplies, or for all water supplies at times of risk or presence of diarrhoea epidemic, water is treated with a disinfectant to achieve free chlorine residual at the tap of 0.5 mg per litre and turbidity is below 5 NTU, 4) If for a short period, water which is contaminated chemically or radiologically is used, no (significant probability of) negative health effect is (likely to be) detected. Domestic use: drinking, cooking and personal hygiene (incl. laundry)

Localisation
LOC-I1: % of budget that went to national and local actors
SSCJR - Joint Humanitarian Response for South Sudan COVID-19 Joint Response

description.narrative: As C-19 has worsened the already precarious situation of many South Sudanese the main objective of the intervention is to reduce the impact of C-19 on 66,000vulnerable people by addressing their immediate Health, WASH and FSL needs in severely affected areas Juba and Rubkona. Protection is mainstreamed and special C-19 measures are taken to protect staff and beneficiaries: Health: To improve case detection and treatment, benefiting 12,000 people, 4 triage centres are established for screening, identification, and detection of suspected C-19 cases. Frontline workers are adequately equipped and trained in C-19 case detection and management/treatment following MoH C-19 guidelines and centres will be provided with supplies and equipment for effective management of suspected/confirmed cases. HF will be provided with IPC WASH support for which Cordaid has developed specific guidelines. RRT will be enabled to conduct investigations and referrals and Bentiu hospital laboratory will be enabled to scale up testing by training and provision of testing materials and staff WASH: To address lack of information, water and hygiene items, C-19 awareness sessions with provision of IEC materials and hygiene items will be provided to 60,000 people. 3 boreholes will be installed in areas consulted with village elders and women and 5 repaired and WMC established. In schools, churches handwashing facilities with rainwater harvesting are installed and IEC materials and soap are provided. In central village locations, tippy taps are installed and provided with information and soap. FSL: To meet immediate food needs of 2,208 most vulnerable, already identified women children and elderly persons cash for food (MEB: EUR85/HH for 3 months) is provided. They also receive seeds, tools and training to address their longer term food needs. With women bearing the brunt of the pandemic, FSL activities will focus on women. 50 women are trained in business skills and rewarded with a start-up grant

As C-19 has worsened the already precarious situation of many South Sudanese the main objective of the intervention is to reduce the impact of C-19 on 66,000vulnerable people by addressing their immediate Health, WASH and FSL needs in severely affected areas Juba and Rubkona. Protection is mainstreamed and special C-19 measures are taken to protect staff and beneficiaries: Health: To improve case detection and treatment, benefiting 12,000 people, 4 triage centres are established for screening, identification, and detection of suspected C-19 cases. Frontline workers are adequately equipped and trained in C-19 case detection and management/treatment following MoH C-19 guidelines and centres will be provided with supplies and equipment for effective management of suspected/confirmed cases. HF will be provided with IPC WASH support for which Cordaid has developed specific guidelines. RRT will be enabled to conduct investigations and referrals and Bentiu hospital laboratory will be enabled to scale up testing by training and provision of testing materials and staff WASH: To address lack of information, water and hygiene items, C-19 awareness sessions with provision of IEC materials and hygiene items will be provided to 60,000 people. 3 boreholes will be installed in areas consulted with village elders and women and 5 repaired and WMC established. In schools, churches handwashing facilities with rainwater harvesting are installed and IEC materials and soap are provided. In central village locations, tippy taps are installed and provided with information and soap. FSL: To meet immediate food needs of 2,208 most vulnerable, already identified women children and elderly persons cash for food (MEB: EUR85/HH for 3 months) is provided. They also receive seeds, tools and training to address their longer term food needs. With women bearing the brunt of the pandemic, FSL activities will focus on women. 50 women are trained in business skills and rewarded with a start-up grant

Cordaid will implement directly and through 2 local partners. In Juba Cordaid is working with the South Sudan Youth Fight against C-19, reaching young people in particular who make up 70% of the population with C-19 awareness and soap. Technical support, FSL and water are provided by Cordaid, complementing the activities of StC, ICCO and HaC. In Rubkona health services are provided by Children Aid South Sudan with technical support from Cordaid, and FSL and WASH is provided by Cordaid. Trained health promotors are selected among the community, enabling the advancement of awareness and enhanced knowledge among local communities. Cash is used but only for food and start up grants for women as it gives people choice and dignity, is more flexible and stimulates local markets. Cordaid has an experienced drilling team and all equipment in place to ensure smooth drilling and rehabilitation of wells. Its C-19 guidelines will ensure quality services and protection for staff and beneficiaries

Cash for people displaced by Kunduz fighting

description.narrative: Following a relatively quiet period, fighting between Afghan National Security Forces (ANSF) and a non-state armed group (NSAG) flared up across the north-east of Afghanistan mainly in Badakhshan, Kunduz and Takhar provinces, resulting in some 9,150 families (approximately 64,050 people) being displaced by ongoing fighting since 16 August in Kunduz province and further displacement is expected. Some 6,670 HH are seeking refuge in Kunduz city, 2,500 HH fled to remote villages in Khanabad District, 1,500 HH in Imam Sahib and 580 HH in Aqtash district (Flash update 2 UNOCHA, 27 August, 2020). Many of the displaced families are staying with relatives or friends, or in rental accomodation while others are living in makeshift substandard shelters or in open spaces. The most urgent needs are shelter, food, Health care and safe drinking water. Due to lack of shelter, food and NFIs these vulnerable groups are experiencing the heat but soon the cold weather will arrive, and are also more prone to GBV and sexual violence. Furthermore, the lack of safe water and sanitation facilities are major public health and protection risks. The temporary shelters are overcrowded, making it impossible for people to follow the COVID-19 advise, further increasing risks on infections. Displacement is affecting women, girls, elderly, ill and disabled disproportionately, increasing their protection risks. Humanitarian partners are supporting local authorities to respond to people in need and have deployed inter-agency assessment teams to affected areas. During the regional cluster meeting on 26 August, both WFP and ECHO (through ERM) agreed to support 1,250 families with cash and food. However, with an estimated 50% (Kunduz Head of DoRR) of the affected people is vulnerable and in need of assistance, the assistance provided is not sufficient. As of yet the current response and attention for this crisis is insufficient. The regional UNOCHA office requested the Kabul UNOCHA office for uregent assistance of additional 2000 HH. There are very clear gaps identified in the response and needs are increasing rapidly especially as fighting continues. The aim of the assistance is therefore to address recently displaced people's most urgent, basic needs, saving lives, preventing the already precarious situation from worsening and families to apply negative coping strategies as many have already depleted their reserves.

Target vulnerable groups from the internally displaced people due to recent conflict in three districts of Kunduz (Kunduz City, Imam Sahib and Khan Abad). Basically those displaced or affected by the fighting and are sheltered in makeshift shelters, in the open and host households of the displaced persons. These vulnerable groups include; women, children, the elderly and chronicaly ill, persons with special needs, and people who's properties have been destroyed by the fighting and are now living in open spaces. for identification of most vulnerable HH, the displacement status with poor food consuption score and high coping startegies will be considered. for the inditification of beneficiraies the HEAT (ICCT endorsed tool) uploaded to the Kobo-Toolbox will be used which also give the realtime information on vulnerability.
To address the pressing needs of the displaced population with one month cash for their expenditure and providing COVID-19 awareness

title.narrative: Unconditional and unrestricted cash
CSH-I1: Number of people benefitting from unconditional and unrestricted cash transfers

description.narrative: Unconditional transfers are provided to beneficiaries without the recipient having to do anything in return in order to receive the assistance . Unrestricted transfers can be used entirely as the recipient chooses i.e. there are no restrictions on how the transfer is spent (Definitions of CALP). It can be delivered e.g. through local banks, shops, traders, local money transfer companies, remittance companies and post offices in either one or several instalments.

title.narrative: Cash for Food for insecure people in Kot and Bati Kot districts of Nangarhar

description.narrative: Cordaid Conducted a raid need assessment during August 2020 in Kot, Bati Kot, Achin and Nazyan districts of Nangarhar. The assessment found that 76% of the respondents holds a National ID and that nearly 70% are under 18 yrs. 54.2% are females and 45.8% males. Half of the responding HH have been displaced or returning IDPs, making them more vulnerable to food insecurity and COVID-19. Because of high coping strategies practised by 82% of the respondents, combined with the vast majority of them (83%) having a poor food consumption score and no available food stocks (99%), people in the assessed areas are severely and acute food insecure. This is compounded by the lack of employment with more than 2/3 of the people being unemployed. Daily unskilled labour opportunities are limited (17%), which may be caused COVID-19 and related measures such as border closure. The effect of the COVID-19 measures is also reflected in people’s income. People saw their income more than halved over the past period, reducing their purchasing power dramatically whilst prices increased. Access to water and sanitation is limited to half of the people, implying that hygiene practices are low. This represents a major public health risk and the situation is now exacerbated by COVID-19. With poor hygiene practices and insufficient access to water for sanitation, people will not be able to take COVID-19 precautionary measures. Although the majority of the people is living in houses, more than half of them live in partially destroyed shelters and nearly half of them are living in overcrowded one-room shelter unable to social-distance. The lack of adequate shelter, water and sanitation facilities and privacy is affecting women and girls in particular, representing a protection risk for women and girls. Furthermore, women and girls are also disproportionately affected by COVID-19, bearing the brunt of the pandemic now as well in addition to displacement and conflict. With winter arriving soon, the assessed people also raised the need for heating materials, warm clothes and blankets. People lack the means to protect themselves against winter and are likely to resort to the use of negative coping strategies which include reduction in number of meals (27%), incurring debts (13%) and 96% will send the children out to collect fire wood, potentially causing protection risks for them. Markets assessments were also conducted and showed that in all 4 target districts, markets were functional and sufficiently stocked with food and NFIs supplies. Marko and Jalalabad were the main markets supplying materials to the districts market. Although markets at district level are small, they have the capacity to restock within 24 hours. At the time of assessment, markets were not facing any shortages of commodities.
The food insecure people in IPC 3 and 4

The overall objective of the project is to increase access to food of COVID-19 affected people who are in IPC phase 3 or phase 4 in Kot and Batikot of Nangarhar, through unconditional cash assistance, contributing to a minimum household food consumption score above 42.5. This will be achieved through cash for food assistance of half food basket for a period of 2 months, to complement beneficiaries' existing food stocks.

title.narrative: Gender Equity Teacher Training (GETT)

description.narrative:
- Girls without parents who are living with relatives - Girls, especially girls with disabilities (including those with physical, learning and/or social emotional needs) - Girls whose parents (one or both) have reduced employment due to Covid - Girls who are unlikely to return to school (early marriage; working, increased caretaking responsibilities of siblings/elders, or other reasons) - Students from chronically poor family, food insecure
Selected students should meet at least two of this criteria to receive a learning basket for their family.
Gender Equity Teacher Training project

To efficiently and effectively prepare, procure, distribute and monitor the outcome of the delivery of learning baskets to approximately 400 students who are considered "vulnerable" in the province of Kandahar.
